screening_results.reason: fMRI study examining social (peer) influence during a social-media task—clearly social processing. However participants are described as adolescents with no ages reported; inclusion criterion requires ages 17–65. Abstract lacks age detail, so include for full-text review to verify participant ages and health status.

This article is a critical review/appraisal, not a primary fMRI study. The abstract reports no methods, participants, or fMRI data from healthy adults performing social tasks, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

Abstract describes a narrative/theoretical review of naturalistic fMRI approaches rather than reporting primary fMRI data or a specific study with participants and methods. Does not indicate a functional MRI scan on healthy adults; therefore does not meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract describes a narrative review/chapter summarizing fMRI findings rather than reporting original fMRI data in healthy adults. It lacks clear information that an original fMRI study with healthy participants (age 17–65) was conducted. Include for full-text review to verify presence of primary fMRI data and healthy subject groups.

The article is explicitly a meta-analysis of over 350 fMRI studies. The exclusion criteria disallow systematic reviews or meta-analyses, so this record should be excluded despite addressing social cognition in (healthy) adults.

This is a review article on resting-state fMRI and social cognition rather than an original fMRI study reporting task-based scans in human participants. It meets the exclusion criterion (systematic review/meta-analysis/review) and does not report task-based social fMRI in healthy adults.

This article is explicitly a review and meta-analysis of social cognition in PTSD, not an original fMRI study in healthy adults. It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses; the abstract gives no primary fMRI data on healthy participants.

The article is a review of fMRI findings in autism spectrum disorders, not an original fMRI study in human participants. The exclusion criteria explicitly remove systematic reviews or meta-analyses; additionally, the focus is on ASD populations rather than healthy adults. Exclude based on abstract alone.

This is a review/chapter discussing frameworks and existing literature rather than an original fMRI study. The abstract describes a theoretical/summary piece with no methods, participants, or reported fMRI data—meets exclusion for non-empirical review.

This is a narrative review integrating human fMRI and animal research, not an original fMRI study with human participants. It meets the exclusion criterion (review/meta-analysis) and does not report primary fMRI data from healthy adults.

The study used resting-state fMRI rather than task-based fMRI. Although social cognition tasks were administered behaviorally, the fMRI was not conducted while participants performed a social-related task, so it fails the inclusion criterion.

fMRI study administering social reward/threat processing and facial affect recognition tasks. Includes a matched healthy control group aged 50–60 (within 17–65). Primary research (not a review). Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Abstract reads like a narrative review of neuroimaging in autism, summarizing multiple PET/SPECT/fMRI studies in autistic patients rather than reporting an original fMRI experiment in healthy adults. It therefore meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses and does not provide evidence of fMRI on healthy 17–65 y/o participants performing social tasks.

Task-free (resting-state) fMRI study; no social-related task was performed during scanning. Although typically-developing controls are included, the study does not meet the inclusion requirement of a task-based social processing fMRI paradigm.

Original fMRI study using a social cognition task (listening to film extracts and inferring mental states). Includes healthy control participants (28 HC, reproducibility sample of 14 HC). Not a review. Fits inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in adults.

Original fMRI study measuring STS responses to social and linguistic stimuli in human participants, directly addressing social perception/cognition. Not a review. Participant health/age not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm age range.

Participants were children aged 8–12, while the review requires healthy adult participants aged 17–65. Although the study uses fMRI and examines social processing, the sample falls outside the age inclusion criterion.

Abstract reports testing neural activity during social vs non-social anticipation and feedback in BPD, but does not explicitly state that fMRI was used nor whether a healthy control group (ages 17–65) was included. Information is insufficient from the abstract alone to confirm inclusion criteria, so include for full-text review.

This paper is a review reappraising social cognition in multiple sclerosis and emphasizes neuropsychological and neuroimaging studies. It is not an original fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults and meets the exclusion criterion for reviews/meta-analyses; participants described are MS patients rather than healthy 17–65-year-olds.

This is a review article (contemporary overview) rather than a primary fMRI study. It does not present original fMRI data on healthy adults and meets the exclusion criterion for reviews/meta-analyses.

This is a methodological review of fMRI reliability (a review article), not a primary fMRI study of social-related tasks in healthy adults. The exclusion criterion 'systematic reviews or meta-analyses' applies; abstract lacks primary data on social task fMRI in healthy participants.
Study used fMRI in macaque monkeys rather than human participants. Inclusion requires functional MRI in healthy adults (age 17–65). Therefore it does not meet participant criteria.

Abstract examines neural substrates of social cognition and face processing in healthy young adults, matching the review objective. However it does not explicitly state that functional MRI was used or describe the task, so full-text review is needed to confirm fMRI and task details.

fMRI study using the Cyberball social inclusion/exclusion paradigm with emotional support in 46 undergraduate participants (healthy adults). The task probes social processing (ostracism and support). Not a review; meets inclusion criteria.

This record is a systematic review of social cognition training in schizophrenia rather than an original fMRI study in healthy adults. It meets the exclusion criterion (systematic review) and does not report fMRI data on a healthy participant group.

The study addresses social-cognitive/empathy processing relevant to the review, but the abstract does not specify whether an fMRI task was used or whether a healthy control group (ages 17–65) was included. Insufficient information to exclude; include for full-text review.
This is a narrative review article (explicitly a review). It does not report original fMRI experiments in healthy adults, meeting the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

fMRI study examining implicit/explicit detection of social signals (eye-gaze, self-propulsion) and mental-state inference in healthy participants. This directly addresses social processing in humans. Abstract does not report participant ages, so include for full-text review to confirm age range and other details.

fMRI study of self–other processing (a social-related task) that includes a healthy, age-matched typically developing control group of young adults (19 participants). Task and participant age range meet inclusion criteria; not a review or meta-analysis.

Not an fMRI original study of social processing in healthy adults. It's a narrative review/proposal about deep brain stimulation for severe autism and reports a case; no functional MRI task or healthy adult participant group described.

This article is a narrative review of semantic dementia (neuroimaging, pathology, genetics), not an original fMRI study. It is a systematic review/meta-review type article and does not report task-based fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI study examining how social information and reward influence decisions in a group foraging task with human participants (groups of three). It investigates social-related processing (integration of others’ behavior) and reports fMRI data; not a review.

This article is a review/meta-analysis (explicitly described as a review and using meta-analytic approaches), not an original fMRI study of healthy participants. Although it addresses social cognition among other domains, it meets the exclusion criterion of being a systematic review/meta-analysis.

fMRI study examining processing of social versus nonsocial gestures (a social-related task) in human participants; abstract implies healthy adult sample and does not indicate a review or clinical-only group. Meets inclusion criteria for social processing fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI study of human subjects performing a dyadic social interaction task, directly addressing social processing. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract implies healthy adult participants (men and women); if participant age/health not explicit, full-text can confirm. Include for full-text review to verify age range and health status.

fMRI BOLD study using a socio-emotional face-preference task (social processing) that includes a healthy control group. Abstract does not report participant ages (17–65); include for full-text review to confirm age eligibility and extract details.

Abstract focuses on first-episode schizophrenia and mentions fMRI mentalizing, but does not state whether a healthy control group (ages 17–65) was included. Because information on presence of healthy participants is insufficient from the abstract, include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

Study participants are children (NVLD, ASD, and typically developing), not healthy adults aged 17–65 required by the review. The abstract also focuses on network connectivity in children and likely not a task-based fMRI in healthy adults. Therefore it does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI was used during spontaneous conversation (a high-social-demand task). The study includes a matched typically developing control group of young adult males (healthy participants within the target age range). Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Abstract is an essay/review proposing cross-species social neuroscience; it does not report an fMRI experiment or human participants performing social tasks. No methods, participants, or data — not eligible as an empirical fMRI study.

Primary fMRI study investigating social-emotional processing (schadenfreude and fremdscham) in healthy adult participants (N=34). Task targets perception/understanding of others (social cognition). Not a review or meta-analysis; meets inclusion criteria.

Original fMRI study in healthy adult participants comparing social vs. solitary contexts during episodic memory tasks; investigates neural representation of social interaction (mPFC). Not a review/meta-analysis and meets inclusion criteria for social-related processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants examining social-interactive processing (mentalizing) during speech perception; directly tests social communication/context and uses functional MRI. Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of social working memory and perspective-taking—clearly a social-related task and neuroimaging. Abstract lacks explicit participant health/age details, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study investigating processing of dynamic facial expressions (social communication/perception) in a sample of 51 participants. Meets social-related task criterion. Abstract does not explicitly report participant ages or confirm 'healthy' status, so include for full-text review to verify eligibility.

Event-related fMRI study comparing responses to social (faces) versus non-social (shapes) targets—directly addresses social processing in an fMRI task. Abstract implies typical/healthy participants (no clinical-only sample), but does not report ages or explicit health status; include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health criteria.

Dual (simultaneous) fMRI hyperscanning performed during an interactive social-exchange task investigating social cognition (cooperation/competition). Study involves human participants in social processing; not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social-related processing in healthy adults; include for full-text review.

Abstract includes healthy control group (N=67) and examines neural bases of biological motion (socially-relevant) but does not specify use of functional MRI or clearly describe the task as an fMRI social-processing task. Insufficient information about imaging modality and task in abstract — include for full-text review.

The article is a meta-analysis of over 200 fMRI studies (systematic review), which meets the exclusion criterion excluding systematic reviews/meta-analyses; it is not an original fMRI study of healthy participants.

fMRI study examining understanding of others' regret—a social cognition task (perception/understanding of others). Abstract reports fMRI during a task observing others’ choices; not a review. Participant health/ages not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm at least one healthy adult group (17–65).

The paper reports meta-analyses of fMRI studies (three MKDA meta-analyses) and lesion work rather than original fMRI data from a primary sample of healthy adults. Per exclusion criteria, meta-analyses/systematic reviews should be excluded.

This article is a review/discussion of resting-state fMRI findings in ASD and attempts at causal manipulation; it does not report an original task-based fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. It therefore meets the exclusion criterion (systematic review/meta-analytic type) and lacks required participant/task data.

This is a narrative review of fMRI and behavioural studies in adolescence, not an original fMRI study with human participants performing a social task. Exclusion criterion: systematic reviews or meta-analyses clearly met.

fMRI study using a social-related face-encoding task with online eye-tracking and includes an age- and gender-matched healthy control group. Abstract does not specify participant ages (17–65 requirement), so include for full-text review to confirm adult age range and extract data.

fMRI study with 36 healthy adult participants performing a social-related task (observing cooperative and affective social interactions). Directly investigates social cognition/neural processing in healthy adults and is an original empirical study (not a review). Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of live social interaction (reciprocal imitation) probing mirror neuron and mentalizing systems — clearly a social-related task in healthy adults likely studied. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicit healthy-only sample; insufficient detail to exclude. Include for full-text screening to confirm participant health/age and extract necessary data.

Abstract describes an fMRI study using a social-cognition task (agency vs. communion), directly relevant to social processing in humans. Participant health status and ages are not specified in the abstract, so full text is needed to confirm eligibility (healthy adults aged 17–65). Include for full-text review.

This is a review/theoretical paper summarizing neuroimaging literature on the cerebellum, not an original fMRI study reporting data from healthy adult participants performing social-related tasks. Abstract lacks empirical methods/participants and appears to be a review, meeting the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

Resting-state fMRI study in children with ASD and typically developing controls; no task-based social processing in healthy adults. Participants are not adult healthy subjects performing a social-related task, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of healthy adult participants (n=38) performing a social interaction task (virtual ball-toss) examining neural responses to social reward. Meets inclusion: functional MRI, social-related processing, healthy adults. Not a review.

Abstract describes fMRI studies of social perception involving typically developing adults and reports original findings on STS function and connectivity; not a systematic review. Abstract describes a narrative review/perspective on adolescent social brain development, summarizing existing structural and fMRI findings and speculating on implications. Abstract reports fMRI conducted during an empathy task (a social cognition construct) and includes a group of healthy control participants matched for age/sex/education. Abstract mentions task-relevant topics (social and non-social cognition) and reports fMRI imaging, but does not specify whether task-based social processing was used or whether healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Insufficient detail in abstract — include for full-text review.

Resting-state fMRI study (no task-based social processing); participants are individuals with autism and controls. Does not meet inclusion requirement of task-based social processing in healthy adults.

Abstract reports only two clinical groups (schizophrenia with SUD and schizophrenia without SUD); no healthy participant group is included. Inclusion requires at least one healthy adult group (age 17–65).

fMRI study investigating theory-of-mind/social interaction processing in humans; meets the review’s social-related task and fMRI criteria. Abstract does not state participant health/ages explicitly, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample (17–65).

Abstract reports fMRI data from 78 healthy individuals performing 29 tasks including explicit ‘social perception and reasoning’ contrasts. This meets the criterion of an fMRI social-related task in healthy adults; not a review/meta-analysis. Include for full-text data extraction.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants performing self-descriptiveness judgments—a social-related task (perception/understanding of self). Not a review/meta-analysis and meets age/participant criteria based on abstract. Include for full-text review.

fMRI social-reward task in healthy human participants addressing social processing. Sample are typically developing adolescents (ages 14–18); abstract does not clarify if a subgroup meets the 17–65 criterion. Include for full-text review to confirm age eligibility and extract relevant data.

This article is a mini-review synthesizing evidence rather than reporting primary fMRI data. The abstract does not describe participants, an fMRI social task, or original data collection. It therefore meets the exclusion criterion for reviews.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants (n=17) viewing love, power-related, and control movie clips—examines affiliation and power motivations (social-related processing). Not a review; meets inclusion criteria for social processing in healthy adults.

Resting-state fMRI study (no social task performed) and participants are children aged 7–12, not healthy adults 17–65 required by the review. Therefore does not meet the inclusion criteria.

fMRI study in 15 healthy adult males using fear-inducing visual stimuli to probe amygdala function and social cognition (oxytocin effects). Task examines social-related processing (trust/social cognition) in healthy adults, meeting inclusion criteria.

Abstract describes an fMRI experiment investigating self-referential and social stimulus processing in humans, directly addressing social-related processing. The abstract describes a narrative review of neuroimaging and behavioral studies in high-functioning autism, not an original fMRI experiment. It reports no fMRI data from human participants performing social-related tasks or any healthy adult sample. Therefore it does not meet inclusion criteria.

This article is a voxel-based meta-analysis (systematic meta-analysis) of fMRI studies rather than an original fMRI study in human participants; exclusion criterion excludes systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

fMRI study used an emotional faces task (social processing—perception/understanding of others). It appears to be primary research with single-subject/healthy participant data and is not a review. This is a review/chapter summarizing oxytocin effects and neuroimaging in ASD, not an original fMRI study reporting primary data. It appears to be a review/meta-analytic chapter and does not report fMRI results in a healthy adult sample, so it meets the exclusion criterion for reviews.

Abstract reports an original fMRI experiment using a social working memory task manipulating social load; it examines neural processing of social information in (presumably) healthy adult participants and is not a review. Abstract appears to be a narrative review focusing on emotion and facial affect recognition in schizophrenia; it mentions fMRI paradigms but does not report an original fMRI study or clearly state inclusion of healthy adult participants. Abstract discusses social cognitive impairments and neural (default/mirror) networks in PTSD but does not state whether an fMRI social-task was performed or whether healthy control participants (age 17–65) were included. fMRI study with healthy adult participants performing attractiveness comparisons (social perception of others). Task targets perception/understanding of others (social-related). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to include.

Abstract focuses on social-executive performance but does not state that fMRI was used nor whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Because the necessary methodological details are missing yet the topic is relevant, include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

fMRI study examining social cognition (trustworthiness and age judgments of faces) that includes a healthy control group. Abstract reports an fMRI study of social hierarchy processing in human participants in an interactive social task, addressing social perception and motivation. This is a large-scale meta-analysis of fMRI studies rather than a primary fMRI study of participants performing social tasks. The exclusion criteria explicitly exclude systematic reviews/meta-analyses, so it should be excluded despite addressing social processing.

This is a selective review article (not an original fMRI study). It meets the exclusion criterion for reviews/meta-analyses and does not report primary fMRI data on healthy participants performing social tasks.

The study is a coordinate-based Activation Likelihood Estimation (ALE) meta-analysis (i.e., a meta-analysis), which meets the exclusion criterion 'systematic reviews or meta-analyses'. Although healthy controls are included, this is not an original fMRI study of participants.

fMRI was used while participants performed a social cognition task (inferring others' emotions with feedback). fMRI study using emotional face stimuli (social processing) and includes a neurotypical control group. Abstract does not report participant ages (17–65 criterion); include for full-text review to confirm age eligibility and extract relevant data.

fMRI study using social-cognitive task (traffic-awareness videos) in adult drivers; probes socio-cognitive processes (understanding others' actions/affect). At least one group appears to be healthy adults. No exclusion criteria met.

fMRI (neuroimaging) study in healthy human adults investigating perception of animacy — a social perception process — while participants viewed motion cues; BOLD responses reported. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI of social-related processing in healthy adults and is not a review.

fMRI study investigating mentalising/theory-of-mind (social cognition) with human participants (fMRI n=17). Relevant to perception/understanding of others. Abstract does not specify participant ages or health status; include for full-text review to confirm participants meet age/health criteria.

fMRI study examining speech acts (Requests vs Naming), a social communication task relevant to review. Abstract does not state participant ages or explicit healthy status, so include for full-text review to confirm sample meets age/health criteria.

fMRI study in which participants imagined social (triadic) interactions—directly addresses social processing. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract implies healthy adult participants performing task; age not specified, so include for full-text verification of sample ages and health. No exclusion criteria met.

fMRI study of self-evaluation (social-related processing) with a matched healthy control group (adults). Meets inclusion criteria (social task; healthy participants present). Not a review or meta-analysis.

fMRI study used a social-cognitive task (affective ToM, emotion recognition) and includes a matched healthy control group; not a review. Age range not specified in abstract, but inclusion justified for full-text confirmation.

fMRI study examining neural responses to social reward (being liked) during a social feedback task in participants aged 18–21. Sample appears to be a healthy/ non-clinical cohort varying in social anhedonia. Meets age (17–65) and social task criteria; not a review.

fMRI experiments investigated human voice recognition, a social-communication task (perception/understanding of others). The study included matched healthy control participants (adults ~32 y), meeting age and healthy-group criteria. Not a review. Abstract truncation limits detail but provides sufficient information to include for full-text review.

fMRI study of live social interaction (human-human vs human-robot) in 21 participants assessing mentalizing and social motivation—directly addresses social processing in humans. Abstract does not explicitly state participants' health status or ages; include for full-text to confirm they are healthy adults (17–65) and extract relevant contrasts.

fMRI study of social-related processing (dynamic facial expressions and social interaction cues) and includes a non-SPD control group of adults (healthy participants). Meets criteria of an fMRI social task with at least one healthy adult group; no exclusion criteria met.

Study involves pediatric stroke patients (children), not healthy adults 17–65, and uses resting-state connectivity rather than a task-based fMRI social-processing paradigm. Does not meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract describes ERP methods and conceptual discussion of emotion processing, development, and neural plasticity; it does not report an fMRI functional scan during a social-related task in healthy adults. It appears to be a review/conceptual paper rather than an original fMRI study, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining self/other social cognition (self, other, game characters) — meets social-related task criterion. Includes a healthy control group, but participants are adolescents and ages not specified; review requires healthy participants aged 17–65. Abstract lacks age detail to confirm adult sample, so include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

Study used simultaneous EEG-fMRI during a group categorization task involving emotional face processing—a clear social-related task. Appears to involve healthy adult participants and is not a review, so meets inclusion criteria.

Study used parametric fMRI while participants evaluated political beliefs, a form of social cognition (self–other processing and social decision-making). No indication the sample was clinical; fits inclusion of healthy adults. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm demographics.

Abstract describes fMRI investigation of face-processing (social cognition) in temporal lobe epilepsy but does not state whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Insufficient information to confirm inclusion criteria, so include for full-text review to determine presence of healthy adult participants and task details.

Study reports fMRI in healthy adult subjects watching realistic movie clips of everyday social interactions, directly assessing social processing. Participants are normal (healthy) adults; task is social-related (perception/understanding of others). Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI was used while participants recalled relationship episodes (social cognition involving perception/understanding of self and others). Sample: 35 healthy individuals (within target adult range). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining neural processing of social interactions (dyadic interaction perception) using multivoxel pattern analysis. Abstract indicates an experiment with human social stimuli and task-related neural responses; however participant health/age not specified. Include for full-text review to confirm sample meets healthy adult (17–65) criterion.

Abstract reports functional MRI during two social-cognitive tasks and links brain activity (superior temporal sulcus, fusiform gyrus) to OXT methylation; participants appear to be healthy individuals and study is primary research (not a review). This meets inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in adults.

Abstract does not state whether an fMRI task was used or whether healthy control participants (age 17–65) were included; it focuses on social-brain connectivity in schizophrenia but provides insufficient information to exclude. Include for full-text review to determine if healthy participants and task-based fMRI meet criteria.

Abstract reports behavioral and fMRI experiments on biological motion perception in schizophrenia and healthy individuals. Biological motion perception falls under social-related processing (perception/understanding of others). The study includes a healthy participant group and is not a review, meeting inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports fMRI decoding using HCP dataset and explicitly states promising decoding performance on social cognition tasks. HCP comprises healthy adult participants, so the study involves fMRI during social-related processing in healthy adults and meets inclusion criteria.
This is an fMRI study in dogs (canine participants), not humans. The review requires fMRI studies with human participants (age 17–65). Therefore it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

Although this is an fMRI study of empathy (a social-related construct) in healthy participants, all participants are older adults (mean age 79), which falls outside the review's required age range (17–65). Therefore it should be excluded based on participant age.

fMRI study where participants performed a social/prosocial learning task (choices affecting self vs. other), examining empathy and neural responses. Participants are human (healthy) adults; not a review. Meets inclusion (social processing in healthy adults) per abstract.

The study reports original fMRI data where subjects encoded facts about unfamiliar people (person-selective responses), addressing social cognition/perception of others. It is not a review. Participant health and exact ages are not specified in the abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult (17–65) sample and other details.

fMRI study of social-affiliative processing: participants (scanned at age 24) completed a social regulation task (friend/stranger/no hand during threat). Sample are healthy adults within 17–65. Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

Original fMRI study probing emotional inference from vocalizations and music—a social communication/perception task in humans. Not a review. Abstract does not state participant ages/health explicitly, so include for full-text screening to confirm participants meet the 17–65 healthy adult criterion.

Functional MRI was used during social-cognition tasks (face processing, emotion recognition, affective ToM). Study includes a healthy matched control group (adult HCs). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

This study used resting-state fMRI in young adults with high-functioning ASD and healthy controls, not an fMRI social-task paradigm. The review requires task-based fMRI during social-related processing; absence of a social task means exclusion based on abstract alone.

fMRI study in healthy human adults investigating attribution of emotions to humans and animals—a social cognitive task assessing perception/understanding of others. Abstract indicates task during scanning and no exclusion criteria (not a review); meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining guilt (a social-emotional process) using tasks that engage social cognition and affective regions. Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages (17–65), so inclusion cannot be confirmed from abstract alone. Include for full-text review to verify healthy adult sample and age range.

Participants are children and adolescents (ASD and matched TD), not healthy adults aged 17–65 required by the review. The study population therefore falls outside the inclusion age range; fMRI social-task criteria also unclear.

Study reports MEG hyperscanning (dual MEG) via an internet audiovisual link, not functional MRI. Does not meet the requirement of an fMRI scan during social task, so excluded based on imaging modality.

The sample consists solely of 47 patients with schizophrenia or schizoaffective disorder; no healthy control group (age 17–65) is reported in the abstract, so it fails the inclusion requirement of at least one healthy participant group.

fMRI social-processing task with a healthy control group is reported, but participants are described as 'youth' with no ages given. Inclusion depends on control group age (17–65). Abstract lacks age details, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

This is a resting-state fMRI connectivity study comparing MDD patients and healthy controls, not a task-based fMRI study of social processing. Although healthy controls are included, no social-related task was performed, so it does not meet the inclusion criterion.

fMRI was used while participants viewed faces of group members to assess neural tracking of others' popularity—a social cognition task (perception/understanding of others). Participants are real-world group members (presumably healthy adults). Study is primary research (not a review) and meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Functional MRI study measuring theory-of-mind (false-belief) processing—a social cognitive task—performed on participants; includes large healthy adult comparison groups (≈480 adults). Not a review/meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

Primary fMRI study with healthy adult participants performing social-cognitive tasks (reflection on self and a friend). Investigates neural correlates of perception/understanding of self and others; meets inclusion criteria.

The study used functional MRI during an interactive task measuring self- and other-initiated joint attention and social cognition in 24 healthy adult participants (ages 18–65). It directly addresses social-related processing with fMRI and is not a review, meeting inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports an fMRI study combined with MEG where participants viewed dynamic facial expressions (a social-cognition task). It addresses social perception/understanding of others. Participant health/ages aren’t specified in the abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and age range.

fMRI study of social interaction (human-human competition) explicitly probes Theory of Mind/mentalizing during a social task; involves healthy subjects. Meets review objective of social processing in healthy adults and is not a review. Age not specified but participants described as healthy subjects (likely adults); include for full-text confirmation if needed.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants (25 females) performing a social task (one-shot prisoner's dilemma) probing social cooperation and neural responses; directly investigates social-related processing and is not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study using healthy adult participants investigating neural responses to others' physical and emotional pain (social cognition/Theory of Mind). Tasks are social-related (perception/understanding of others) and meet inclusion criteria; not a review/meta-analysis.

Abstract does not state that a social task was used or that healthy adult participants (17–65) were included; likely a connectivity study in ASD, possibly resting-state. Insufficient information to determine inclusion—include for full-text review.

Study used fMRI to assess facial emotion perception (a social processing task). The abstract does not clearly state a healthy control group aged 17–65; 'nonpsychotic relatives' could be healthy but this is unclear. Include for full-text review to confirm presence and ages of healthy participants and ensure task meets social-processing criteria.

fMRI was conducted while healthy participants performed a communicative/collaborative memory retrieval task that engages mentalizing/theory-of-mind regions (social processing). The abstract states participants were healthy humans but does not report ages, so include for full-text verification of age eligibility.

fMRI study where healthy adult participants read literary passages varying in social content; neural responses to social cognition (dmPFC) were measured. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults and is not a review.

The paper is explicitly a review ('In this review') integrating behavioral and fMRI literature rather than reporting original fMRI data. It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses and provides no primary fMRI results in healthy adults.

fMRI study directly examines social cognition constructs (empathy, Theory of Mind, self-other differentiation) relevant to the review. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages (17–65), so insufficient information to confirm inclusion criteria—include for full-text review to verify participant demographics/health.

Event-related fMRI study of interpersonal resource conflict involving human participants performing a social task (sharing/competition). No indication of clinical population; clearly assesses social processing in adults. Fits inclusion criteria; include for full-text review to confirm ages/health status and extract relevant data.

fMRI study examining social cognition (emotion and understanding of others) during legal decision-making; participants performed a social-related task. Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adults (17–65) and other eligibility details.

Abstract reports an fMRI investigation of emotional sentence attribution (a social cognitive task) in schizophrenia but does not state whether healthy control participants (age 17–65) were included. It is not a review. Insufficient information to confirm presence of healthy adults; include for full-text review.

Pharmaco-fMRI study where healthy adult participants (large sample of men and women) played an iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma with human partners—a clear social-processing task during fMRI, meeting inclusion criteria.

The paper is a quantitative review/meta-analysis (activation likelihood estimation) of fMRI studies in clinical high-risk for psychosis. Exclusion criteria disallow systematic reviews or meta-analyses; thus exclude based on study design (secondary analysis) rather than primary fMRI data.

This is a review article discussing genetics and neural systems in autism, not an original fMRI study. It does not report fMRI data from healthy adults performing social tasks; thus it meets the exclusion criterion for reviews.

The study used functional near-infrared spectroscopy (fNIRS) rather than functional MRI. Although it addresses social cognition in healthy adults, it fails the required fMRI modality inclusion criterion.

fMRI study in 16 healthy volunteers performing a social interaction task (matching-pennies) with human, android, robots, and computer; examines perception/understanding of others and social brain networks. Meets inclusion (social task, healthy adults). Not a review.

fMRI study of social-related processing (Cyberball exclusion and decision-making in a Dictator Game) in human participants. fMRI study using a social-cognition task (theory of mind and empathy) with healthy human participants (13 right-handed healthy volunteers). Functional imaging during social-related tasks fits the review objective; not a review/meta-analysis. Include for full-text review.

fMRI used the Monetary Incentive Delay task (non-social reward task), not a social-related task; participants were adolescents (not adults 17–65). Both factors make the study outside inclusion criteria.

Study used fMRI during a facial emotional processing (social) task in adults and included a healthy control group matched for age/IQ. Fits inclusion criteria (social task; healthy adults). No exclusion criteria met.

Empirical fMRI study examining neural correlates of empathy (social cognition) during a task comparing responses to others' pain; involves human participants (presumably healthy adults) and reports task-based fMRI results. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient evidence to include for full-text data extraction.

fMRI study using a social cognition/ToM task (social decision about shapes) and includes a healthy control group (CON). Task assesses perception/understanding of others. Not a review. Age range not specified but participants are adults; nonetheless criteria met for inclusion. Full text can confirm ages if needed.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants performing a social-communication task (communicative speech vs description) involving social interaction and familiarity; directly addresses social processing in humans and is not a review or meta-analysis.

Study used fMRI during a social-interaction discrimination task (perception/understanding of others) and includes a healthy adult group aged 20–41, which meets the review’s age range (17–65). No exclusion criteria apply.

fMRI study of impression formation/person evaluation—a social cognitive task (perception/understanding of others). Uses task-based fMRI and reports neural responses (VMPFC). Study uses resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based social processing paradigm. Inclusion requires fMRI during a social-related task; abstract does not report task-based social processing despite including healthy controls.

Abstract reports fMRI during biological motion processing (social perception) and includes a group of healthy matched controls. Task probes perception of others (social cognition). Not a review/meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria for fMRI social-related processing in healthy adults.

fMRI was conducted in healthy adult participants performing an empathy/social task (viewing human and animal suffering), addressing perception/understanding of others. Functional MRI study with healthy adult participants (n=64) performing a social cognition task (inferring others' preferences/mentalizing). Fits inclusion criteria (perception/understanding of others) and is primary research, not a review.

The study used fMRI to assess neural responses to social exclusion (a social-related task) in 21 healthy volunteers, directly addressing social processing in healthy adults. It is an original experimental study, not a review, and fits the review objective.

fMRI was conducted while participants watched emotional movies probing perception and sharing of others' emotional states, which maps onto social-related processing (perception/understanding of others; social interaction). Participants appear to be healthy adults and no exclusion criteria apply. Age not specified in abstract, but insufficient detail would warrant full-text review—nevertheless study is relevant for inclusion.

fMRI study examining perception of others’ goal-directed hand actions (social perception) with a healthy adult group (n=31) alongside a patient group. Task fits 'Perception and Understanding of Others' and includes healthy participants within the eligible age range. Not a review or meta-analysis.

Participants are adolescents (age 16–17 years) rather than adults; the meta-analysis requires at least one group of healthy participants aged 17–65. Although the study uses fMRI of social/emotional introspection, the sample falls outside the required adult age range.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants performing an imitation task probing spontaneous imitation/urge to imitate, which relates to social interaction and social communication. Fits review objective of social-related processing in healthy adults; not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information for inclusion.

Resting-state fMRI in children and adolescents with ASD (and controls); not a task-based fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults aged 17–65. Does not meet task-based and adult participant criteria.

fMRI was used during a visual perspective-taking task (social-cognitive processing) and the study included a healthy adult control group (20 participants). Not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.
Participants are infants (3–7 months), not healthy adults aged 17–65 as required by the review; therefore study does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study in healthy adult physicians (ages 25–37) performing a social task (doctor–patient interaction/treatment) examining empathy/ reward neural correlates — directly addresses social processing in healthy adults; not a review.

Participants were children/adolescents (ASD and typically developing), not adults. The review requires at least one healthy participant group aged 17–65; this study does not meet the age criterion despite using fMRI for social processing.

fMRI study of improvised joint action (leading/following/mutual) involving trained couple dancers; examines social-cognitive processes (social cognition, mentalizing, social reward) during interactive task. Healthy adult participants implied. Not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

The abstract states this paper is a meta-analysis across 12 fMRI studies; exclusion criterion specifies systematic reviews or meta-analyses. It is not an original fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults.

This is an animal (canine) fMRI study with dogs as participants rather than human adults. The review requires fMRI studies in healthy human participants aged 17–65, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

fMRI was used during a face-processing (social perception) task and results were compared to control (healthy adult) participants. This meets the requirement of at least one healthy adult group performing a social-related task. No exclusion criteria are met.

fMRI was performed during visual exposure to emotional facial expressions (social-related processing). The study includes matched healthy young adult controls (within 17–65). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Task-based fMRI of social processing (action-intention judgment) with a typically developing (healthy) participant group reported. Abstract does not state participant ages (17–65 required), so full-text review needed to confirm age range. No exclusion criteria met.

fMRI study examining empathy/attachment (imagining loved-one vs stranger) clearly fits social-related processing constructs. Primary fMRI study of face processing (faces vs objects), which counts as social-related processing (perception/understanding of others). Sample spans 6 years through adulthood, implying inclusion of healthy adults (within 17–65). Not a review.

fMRI was conducted while healthy adult participants (n=15) watched and rated short movie clips of social (guest-host) interactions — a social-cognition task. Participants appear to be healthy adults and the study is empirical fMRI work, not a review.

Although exact ages are not provided, the presence of a younger adult group implies inclusion of participants likely within the 17–65 range. Not a review or meta-analysis.

fMRI study of action observation/execution examining how observers process others’ effort—fits ‘Perception and Understanding of Others’ social processing. Abstract does not report ages/health explicitly, so include for full-text review to confirm participant ages/health; not a review/meta-analysis.

Participants are preschool-aged children (ASD and typically developing), not healthy adults aged 17–65. No group of healthy adult participants is present, so study does not meet inclusion criteria for adult fMRI social-processing studies.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants performing a social gaze-following task examining social attention and ideological/in-group effects. Empirical fMRI study investigating neural systems for social cognition/action understanding in human participants; not a review. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text verification of participant ages and details.

Primary empirical fMRI study in human participants performing a social cognition task (comparing romantic partner and roommate), addressing perception/understanding of others. Likely healthy adult sample, not a review or meta-analysis — meets inclusion criteria.

Resting-state fMRI in a sample of multiple sclerosis patients with no mention of a healthy control group; no task-based social processing was performed. Does not meet inclusion criteria requiring task-based fMRI and at least one healthy adult group (17–65).

fMRI study of a social-related task (Theory of Mind) including a healthy control group. Although ages are not specified in the abstract, the study involves adult participants and is not a review, so it meets inclusion criteria for social fMRI in healthy adults.

Participants are children (ages 9–13), which does not meet the review’s age inclusion criterion of 17–65. Although the study uses fMRI on social cognition, the sample age clearly excludes it from this review.

Study used BOLD fMRI in healthy participants performing affective and cognitive Theory of Mind tasks (social processing). Primary fMRI study investigating theory-of-mind/social cognition during cooperative vs competitive interactions in humans. Published empirical NeuroImage article with healthy adult participants implied; meets inclusion of social-related task during fMRI. Not a review; include for full-text review.

Human fMRI study in healthy adult participants using a social interaction task (provocation/retaliation) relevant to social processing. Meets inclusion criteria (social-related task; healthy adult group). Not a review or meta-analysis.

Abstract reports fMRI connectivity in high-functioning adolescents with ASD versus typically developing adolescents, but does not state participant ages or whether an active social-related task was used (could be resting-state). Study uses fMRI to examine effects of an implied social presence on brain networks linked to social cognition/theory of mind, matching the review’s social-processing objective. Participants are children (ASD and age-matched typically developing children), not healthy adults aged 17–65. Does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring at least one group of healthy participants aged 17–65.

Event-related fMRI study of moral reasoning (a social cognition task involving empathy/understanding of others) that includes a healthy control group matched for age. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults and is not a review.

The study used resting-state fMRI rather than a social-related task. Although healthy controls were included, the review requires task-based fMRI during social processing; the abstract clearly describes resting-state functional connectivity, so it does not meet the inclusion criterion.

fMRI study in healthy young adult men (n=55) performing social-related tasks (attachment/erotic and fearful social scenes); meets inclusion criteria (social processing, age range, healthy participants). Not a review.

This is a resting-state fMRI study (ABIDE data) comparing ASD and controls; no task-based social processing paradigm is used. The review requires task fMRI of social-related processing in healthy adults, so it does not meet inclusion.

fMRI was used while participants performed social-related tasks (IAT on attitudes toward adultery, go/no-go and date-rating assessing interest in unfamiliar potential partners), involving affiliation/attachment and social perception; participants are healthy adult males in relationships; not a review. fMRI study in healthy human adults investigating perception of others' head-turn direction—a dynamic social attention cue—using multivariate pattern analysis in STS. Fits social-related processing in healthy adults and is not a review.

fMRI study probes social cognition (mentalizing/perception of others) during listening to literary fiction, matching review objective. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicitly confirm healthy status; include for full-text review to confirm eligibility (age 17–65 and healthy).

Study used fMRI to examine implicit facial emotion recognition, which is a social-processing task. Abstract reports an fMRI study in which pairs of friends performed a social-sharing task while one underwent fMRI; it examines social/affiliation processing and reports neural activation (ventral striatum, mOFC). fMRI study presenting dynamic and static facial expressions (social stimuli) assessing perception/processing of others’ emotions. Participants are 4- and 6-year-old children with no healthy adult (age 17–65) group reported. Does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring at least one group of healthy adults.

Study used real-time fMRI while volunteers played the ultimatum game (a social interaction/economic decision-making task), fitting social-related processing. The study reports an fMRI task addressing body checking (self-perception), which could fit the review’s social-related construct (Perception/Understanding of Self). fMRI study in healthy human participants performing a social interaction task (iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma). Addresses social processing constructs; participants described as healthy adults. Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

This article is an ALE meta-analysis of fMRI studies on social-cognitive deficits after traumatic brain injury. It is a meta-analysis/systematic review rather than a primary fMRI study of healthy adults, meeting the exclusion criterion for reviews/meta-analyses.

Study used functional MRI while adults (including a matched healthy control group) considered social interactions, directly addressing social-related processing. At least one healthy adult group is present and age range fits. Not a review. Satisfies inclusion criteria.

The abstract reports an fMRI experiment in healthy adult participants examining perception of in-group vs out-group actions — a social perception task (perception/understanding of others). Abstract discusses fMRI and example attempts but does not report clear methods, participant ages, or actual fMRI data in healthy adults. Insufficient information to confirm inclusion criteria; full-text review needed to determine if primary fMRI study with healthy adults was conducted.

fMRI study of joint attention and representing another person’s visual contents—clearly a social-cognition task (perception/understanding of others). fMRI study investigated face emotion discrimination (a social-cognition task) in a community sample comparing high vs low social anhedonia; participants are healthy adults and task probes social processing. fMRI study using point-light displays of biological motion—a social-related task involving perception/understanding of others; reports cerebro-cerebellar connectivity relevant to social cognitive processing. fMRI study of social cognition (irony comprehension) with 15 healthy female controls and 15 patients; meets criterion of at least one group of healthy participants performing a social-related task. Ages not specified in abstract, so include for full-text verification.

Healthy comparison group consists of adolescents (study focuses on adolescents); inclusion requires healthy participants aged 17–65 (adults). Therefore the study does not meet the age criterion for inclusion.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants (N=55 males) performing a social-related task (direct vs. averted gaze). Fits review objective of social processing in healthy adults; not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text data extraction.

fMRI BOLD study with 25 healthy adult female participants performing a social-cognitive task about kin and friends; directly examines social cognition constructs and meets inclusion criteria (healthy adults, task-based fMRI). Not a review.

fMRI study in humans using empathy-evoking film clips assessing social cognition (empathic concern) and neural connectivity. Not a review. Abstract does not report participant ages or explicitly state 'healthy', so include for full-text review to confirm age range and health status.

fMRI study of empathy/perspective-taking (social cognition) in eighteen healthy participants; task involves perception/understanding of others (pain empathy). Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.
Participants are children (mean age 10.2 years), not within the required adult age range (17–65). Although an fMRI social-processing task was used, the sample age fails the inclusion criterion.

Abstract describes fMRI of negative emotion processing but does not state a social-related task or clearly specify healthy adult sample. Insufficient information to rule in/out inclusion; per instructions include for full-text review.

fMRI study of action understanding engaging mental-state reasoning and action-representation networks (social cognition). fMRI study examining brain activity during observation of social interactions and gaze, addressing social cognition (Perception/Understanding of Others). Abstract reports an event-related fMRI study directly examining neural processing of social versus nonsocial gestures (social cognition constructs). fMRI was used while participants performed a social interactive task vs a non-social control, examining social cognition networks in human subjects. Study used fMRI during the Reading the Mind in the Eyes Test (social cognition/emotion recognition) in 16 healthy young adult women, meeting the social-related task and healthy adult participant criteria. Not a review; inclusion appropriate based on abstract.

Study reports task-based fMRI during social cognition (theory of mind) and executive tasks, includes an age-matched healthy control group, and involves adult participants. No exclusion criteria met; suitable for full-text review for eligibility confirmation.

fMRI study of self-referential processing (a social-related construct) that includes a healthy control group alongside schizophrenia patients. The abstract does not report participant ages (17–65 criterion unclear), so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study presenting the EmpaToM task that independently manipulates empathy and Theory of Mind in healthy adult samples (N=90 and N=178).
