Abstract reports human fMRI examining voice processing, which is social communication/perception of others. It uses task-based fast fMRI showing voice-sensitive auditory cortex responses. No exclusion criteria are met. Participant health and exact ages are not specified in the abstract, so full-text review is needed to confirm inclusion criteria (healthy adults 17–65).

Original fMRI study using MVPA examining neural representation of others' mental states (social cognition). Not a review/meta-analysis. Although ages/health not stated in abstract, typical sample likely healthy adults; study clearly addresses social-related processing with fMRI, so include for full-text review.

Study used resting-state fMRI following intranasal oxytocin in healthy volunteers and did not report any task or task-based social processing. Does not meet inclusion criterion requiring functional MRI during a social-related task.

fMRI study of adolescents viewing parent videos (social stimuli) assessing neural responses linked to social cognition; participants mean age 17 (within 17–65 criterion) and appear healthy. Study addresses social processing in humans and is not a review.

fMRI study investigating effects of social gaze on action control using a social vs nonsocial stimulus-response task. Involves healthy adult participants and examines social-related processing (social gaze, social cognition). Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient detail to meet inclusion criteria.

Study II reports an fMRI scan during an interactive social gaze paradigm and includes a healthy control group (16 controls). The task assesses social reward/interaction processing, matching the review constructs. No exclusion criteria met; include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and details.

Abstract addresses theory-of-mind/mentalization (social processing) and discusses functional neuroimaging of the mPFC; however, it does not explicitly state methods, participant details, or that fMRI was performed on healthy adults. Insufficient methodological detail in abstract to confirm inclusion criteria, so include for full-text review to verify fMRI during a social task and participant characteristics.

Participants are children with benign childhood epilepsy (BCECTS), not healthy adults aged 17–65; study examines a clinical pediatric population, so it does not meet the inclusion criterion of healthy adult participants.

This is a resting-state fMRI study (no social-related task performed). Inclusion requires task-based fMRI during a social processing task; although healthy controls are included, the absence of a social task means it does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study with healthy late-adolescent participants (ages 18–22). Task involved observing others’ risk-taking vs safe actions, addressing social perception/understanding and emotional/social cognition. Fits age range (17–65) and social-related processing criteria; not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information for inclusion.

fMRI study of emotional face processing (explicit vs implicit emotion recognition), a social perception/communication task, in 29 healthy participants. Not a review or meta-analysis. Age range not specified in abstract but participants are described as healthy adults—include for full-text verification of exact ages and other details.

fMRI study in normal adult volunteers viewing videos of positive/negative social encounters — directly assesses social processing in healthy adults. Not a review/meta-analysis; meets inclusion criteria based on abstract.
Sample consists of adolescents aged 9–17 (N=34) with no separate healthy adult group within the required 17–65 age range. Therefore it does not meet the age inclusion criterion for healthy adults.

fMRI study examining neural representations of self (social cognition) across cultures using healthy adult participants; meets criterion of functional MRI during a social-related task (self-processing). Age range not specified in abstract — include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants performing a social-related task (viewing others in pain; perception/understanding of others). Age range appears to be adults; not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study with 22 healthy adult participants examining CT-targeted affective touch (social touch). The task probes social perception and social cognition (affiliation/attachment, perception of others); not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social-related processing in healthy adults.

Task-based fMRI study examining self- and other-related social cognition; includes a healthy control group (adult controls) contrasted with BPD participants. Meets inclusion: social-related fMRI task and presence of healthy adults aged within range. Not a review/meta-analysis.

fMRI study examining processing of different laughter types (social communication) with implicit/explicit task manipulations in human participants. Investigates social-related perception and neural connectivity; not a review. Abstract does not state participant ages/health explicitly, but clearly meets the social-related fMRI task criterion — include for full-text to confirm participant demographics and eligibility.

The study uses fMRI during self- and other-reflection, which are social-related processes relevant to the review. The abstract does not specify whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included; insufficient information to confirm, so include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

Task-based fMRI in 25 healthy adult participants examining facial color processing, a social-communication cue relevant to perception/understanding of others. Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI studies in healthy adults.

Task-based fMRI study examining neural correlates of self-evaluation and endorsement of others’ evaluation—clearly a social-cognition task (Perception and Understanding of Self). Abstract does not report participant ages or explicit health status; information is insufficient to confirm sample fits 17–65 healthy criteria, so include for full-text review to verify eligibility.

Participants are adult male incarcerated offenders; the abstract does not indicate any healthy control/healthy participant group. Meta-analysis requires at least one group of healthy adults (age 17–65), so this study does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of social cognition is relevant, but abstract does not state whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Insufficient information to confirm inclusion criterion; include for full-text review to verify presence of healthy participants and ages.

fMRI was conducted while participants played an iterated Prisoner’s Dilemma — a social decision-making task probing cooperation/trust. Study used 20 healthy adult male participants (within 17–65) in a placebo-controlled crossover design. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults; not a review.

Abstract reports collection of simultaneous fMRI during a social interaction (a deception game between pairs), indicating an fMRI social-related task in human participants. Not a review/meta-analysis. Participant ages/health not specified in abstract; include for full-text to confirm demographics.

fMRI study with 18 healthy adult participants performing a social motor response learning task that involves social interaction and inference about others’ intentions (mirror-neuron/frontal operculum). Meets inclusion criteria for social-related processing in healthy adults; not a review or meta-analysis.

The study used fMRI to examine Theory of Mind (a social cognition/Perception and Understanding of Others task) and explicitly included healthy comparison subjects. It therefore meets the fMRI + social-related task criteria and includes a healthy adult group, so it should be included for full review.

Original fMRI study examining multimodal perception of nonverbal emotional signals (voice and face), a social-related processing task. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not explicitly report participant ages/health, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and age range.

fMRI study in human participants performing a social cognition task (forming/updating impressions of others). No indication it is a review; likely healthy adult participants. Fits the review objective of social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study of neural responses to facial expressions (social processing). Includes a healthy control group (no family history of autism). Abstract does not specify participant ages (17–65), so include for full-text review to confirm age range and eligibility.

fMRI data collected while participants performed a social-perception task (perceiving/sex-categorizing interacting person dyads). Study involves social-related neural processing in (presumably) healthy adults and is an original fMRI study, not a review. Age range not reported in abstract; include for full-text verification.

Study used fMRI with an eyes task targeting Theory of Mind/social cognition, matching the review focus. Abstract does not specify ages or whether a healthy adult group (17–65) was included. Insufficient participant info—include for full-text screening to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study examining processing of emotional facial expressions (social communication/perception of others) in human participants. Abstract does not state participant ages or explicit health status, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Event-related fMRI study of healthy adults assessing trustworthiness of faces (social perception of others). Task is social-related; not a review. Abstract indicates neural responses during social judgment, meeting inclusion criteria. Abstract provides sufficient info for inclusion.

Task-free (resting-state) fMRI study examining anterior temporal lobe connectivity with the language network in healthy adults; no social-related task or social processing measures described, so it does not meet the inclusion criterion of a task-based social fMRI.

Uses fMRI during a social-perception task (point-light biological motion vs scrambled), examines neural systems for perception/understanding of others. Includes an adult sample and appears to study healthy participants. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

Abstract reports a neuroimaging study of interpersonal synchrony (a social/affiliation task) with healthy adult participants and identifies brain areas implicated in social cognition. Imaging modality (fMRI) and exact participant ages are not explicitly stated in the abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm that functional MRI was used and that participants meet the age/health criteria.

Abstract reports task-related fMRI during a social perception experiment and includes a healthy control group (21 adults). It directly addresses social-related processing and is an original fMRI study (not a review), meeting inclusion criteria.

Primary data fMRI study using hyperscanning while participants performed joint-attention tasks (social cognitive processing). Involves human participants (presumably healthy adults) and directly assesses perception/understanding of others; not a review or meta-analysis.

Hyperscanning fMRI study of human dyads performing a joint-attention social task—directly addresses social processing in interaction. Appears to involve healthy participants and fits the review objective. Abstract does not specify participant ages or full sample details, so include for full-text review to confirm age range and health status.

Resting-state fMRI study with obese patients and lean controls; no social-related task was performed. Although the abstract mentions regions linked to social cognition, it does not test social processing in a task-based fMRI in healthy adults.

The article is a review of seven structural/functional MRI studies in ADHD samples, not an original fMRI study in healthy adults. It is a review paper (excluded per exclusion criteria) and the participant groups are clinical (ADHD), so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

This is a resting-state fMRI study (no social-related task) conducted in male adolescents, including a conduct disorder group and typically developing adolescents. It does not include healthy adult participants aged 17–65 performing a social task, so it does not meet the review’s inclusion criteria.

Study used resting-state fMRI (no task), so it does not assess neural responses during a social-related task. Although healthy controls were included, the inclusion criteria require task-based fMRI of social processing; therefore exclude.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of laughter perception (social communication/social cognition) in humans. While participant ages and health status are not specified, the study clearly examines social-related processing; include for full-text review to confirm participant age range and health criteria.

fMRI study investigating Theory of Mind (perception/understanding of others) using an active task in human participants; not a review. Abstract implies healthy adult subjects; include for full-text to confirm ages.

fMRI study examining integration of speaker characteristics and sentence content—core social communication/perception processes. Includes a matched healthy adult control group (adults), meeting age criterion. Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info that the task is social-related and that healthy participants were scanned.

fMRI study in healthy adult mothers viewing own vs unfamiliar child/dog—task probes affiliation/attachment and social processing. Participants are adults within the target age range and it is an original empirical fMRI study, not a review.

Task-based fMRI study of self-reference vs. reference to others, directly addressing social cognition (perception/understanding of self and others). Abstract reports human fMRI data but does not specify participant health status or ages. Because the social-related task is clearly present but participant details are insufficient in the abstract, include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.
The study used resting-state fMRI (no task) in healthy adults; inclusion requires a task-based fMRI during social-related processing. Therefore it does not meet the primary inclusion criterion.

Hyperscanning fMRI study of real-time mutual eye contact — a social interaction task (perception/understanding of others/social communication). Participants were healthy adult pairs (16 pairs, ages within 17–65 implied). Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient detail to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining neural responses to third-person social interactions (perception/understanding of others). Participants performed tasks while viewing social biological motion; not a review. Abstract does not state ages/health explicitly, but meets review topic—include for full-text confirmation of healthy adult sample and age range.
Participants are adolescents (ages 12–15), outside the required adult age range (17–65). No healthy adult group is reported. Although this is an fMRI social task, the age criterion is not met.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants (28 women, ages within 17–65) performing a social perception task (viewing animations of social interactions). Reports neural responses during social vs. size attention contrasts. Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI was conducted while participants performed an empathy-for-pain task (viewing painful vs. control stimuli), which is social-related processing (perception/understanding of others). The study includes a group of healthy young adults aged 20–30 (within the 17–65 inclusion age range). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text extraction.

fMRI study examining neural correlates of framing in evaluations of personal attributes—clearly a social-cognition/self-perception task. Abstract describes use of healthy participants (no clinical groups reported) but does not state ages; insufficient age/health detail for final determination, so include for full-text review.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants (n=21) performing an affective theory-of-mind task (inferring others' emotions from stories and facial expressions), which is social cognition/perception of others. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study investigating neural correlates of social understanding/social processing; includes a matched healthy adult control group (23 adults) alongside ASD participants. Participants described as adults (within 17–65). Not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

The study used resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based social processing paradigm, and focuses on schizophrenia (clinical group). It does not report fMRI during a social-related task in healthy adults, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

Participants are healthy children and adolescents aged 10–17 with no adult-only group within the target age range (17–65). The meta-analysis requires fMRI data from healthy adults (17–65); this study focuses on minors, so it should be excluded.

fMRI study with 19 healthy adult participants performing a Theory-of-Mind (social cognition) task (REMICS). Investigates social processing (mental state inference/contextual adjustment). Not a review; meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study where healthy participants viewed animated characters making angry vs. happy expressions — a clear social-perception/communication task (perception/understanding of others). No indication this is a review or that participants were non-healthy. Meets inclusion criteria; include for full-text review.

fMRI was conducted during an interactive mentalizing (social cognition) task; the study includes a healthy typically-developed control group (ages 18–34) meeting the 17–65 criterion. The task targets social processing (Perception/Understanding of Others). Not a review. Sufficient information for inclusion.

Abstract states participants were 'adolescents' (typically developing adolescents and those with ASD). No healthy adult (age 17–65) group is reported, so the study does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring at least one healthy adult group.

Participants are children aged 7–12 years; inclusion criterion requires healthy adult participants aged 17–65. Although the study uses fMRI and examines social processing, the sample does not meet the age range, so it should be excluded.

The study used resting-state fMRI collected after cTBS, not an fMRI scan during a social-related task. Although the targeted SI relates to action observation/execution, no task-based social processing was performed during scanning, so it fails the inclusion criterion.

Participants are patients with amnestic mild cognitive impairment (a-MCI); the abstract does not report any healthy adult (17–65) group. Although the task involves social/emotional processing (face-name associations), the inclusion criterion requiring at least one healthy participant group is not met.

Not a human task-based fMRI study: this is an animal (rat) resting-state fMRI study under anesthesia with no social-related task and participants are not human adults (17–65). Does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining cortical responses to vocal vs nonvocal sounds (socially relevant auditory processing). Likely includes a comparison to typical activation (healthy controls), addressing social communication/perception. Abstract does not explicitly state presence/age range of healthy adult participants, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study with 34 healthy adult participants performing naturalistic movie-viewing that probes social interaction processing (DMPFC responses). This directly addresses social cognition in healthy adults and is an original empirical fMRI report (not a review).

Abstract reports fMRI in 13 patients with PTSD with pre/post-therapy scans; no healthy control or healthy participant group (age 17–65) is described. Does not meet criterion requiring at least one healthy participant group.

Study reports task-based functional MRI (dual-fMRI) during social interactions (cooperation vs. competition), directly addressing social processing. It is an original empirical fMRI study, not a review. Although participant ages/health are not specified in the abstract, there is no indication of clinical groups; include for full-text review to confirm eligibility and demographics.

Abstract reports fMRI in patients with psychotic disorder; no healthy control or healthy participant group (age 17–65) is mentioned. Meta-analysis requires at least one healthy participant group, so exclude.

fMRI study examining mirror neuron responses and emotion processing—central to social cognition (perception/understanding of others). Participants appear to be healthy adults and task is social-related. Abstract supports inclusion; age not specified but typical adult sample. Include for full-text review.

fMRI social perspective-taking task performed; includes a typically developing (healthy) participant group. However, healthy participants are adolescents aged 12–19 and abstract does not confirm they meet the review’s age range (17–65). Insufficient age information — include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

fMRI study examining empathy/self–other representation (social processing: perception/understanding of others). Abstract reports neural responses to friend vs stranger using fMRI; likely healthy adult participants though age/health not specified. Insufficient participant demographics in abstract—include for full-text review.

fMRI study of face processing (social perception/understanding of others) with healthy control group (21 adults) and a clinical group; task is social-related (encoding/recognition of faces). Not a review. Satisfies inclusion criteria.

fMRI was used while participants performed prayer, a social-related task; results report recruitment of social-cognition regions (mPFC, TPJ, precuneus). Participants are human (Danish Christians), presumably healthy adults; no exclusion criteria met. Include for full-text review to confirm ages and participant health.

Task-based fMRI study using a validated Theory of Mind (Reading the Mind in the Eyes) social-cognition task in healthy adult volunteers (right-handed males). Meets inclusion (social-related fMRI in healthy participants aged within 17–65). Not a review or meta-analysis and no exclusion criteria met.

fMRI study examining cortical responses to faces (neutral and fearful), addressing perception/understanding of others — a social-processing task. Participants appear to be healthy observers; ages not specified in abstract. No exclusion criteria met; include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and details.

fMRI study measuring brain responses while participants read a literary text; results report activation in medial frontal and temporo-parietal regions linked to social cognition and predictive inference. Abstract indicates social-related processing; no exclusion criteria met. Participant health/ages not specified—include for full-text verification.

The study included only schizophrenia participants (two patient groups; N=22) and did not include any healthy control or healthy participant group. Inclusion criteria require at least one group of healthy adults (age 17–65).

fMRI study manipulating sociality and social working memory (n-back) in humans; targets social cognition/face processing (perception/understanding of others). Likely healthy adult participants and not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study examining perception of facial and vocal emotional expressions (social communication/perception of others). No indication it is a review; participants appear to be healthy adults. Abstract lacks ages, but meets inclusion for social-related fMRI in healthy participants — include for full-text review to confirm demographics.

fMRI study where participants performed a social-related task (IAT with faces/names of politicians) and reported neural activations in social brain regions (vmPFC, amygdala, PFC, fusiform). Include for full-text review to confirm participant health status and ages.

fMRI study of causal attributions and self-serving bias during attributional decision tasks (social cognition: perception/understanding of self). Abstract refers to ‘normal subjects’ (healthy adults). Not a review—meets inclusion criteria.

This is an fMRI neuroimaging study examining perception of social interactions (observing two agents), a social-related task in humans. It appears experimental (not a review) and likely uses healthy adult participants; ages/health are not specified in the abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Randomized within-subject pharmaco-fMRI in 40 adult males assessing neural and emotional responses to interpersonal touch (a social communication task). Involves healthy adult participants and measures social-related processing with fMRI. Not a review. Meets inclusion criteria based on the abstract.

fMRI study in 19 healthy volunteers performing social-evaluative tasks (guilt and embarrassment), examining neural substrates of social cognition/ToM. Fits inclusion: functional MRI during social-related task in healthy adults. Not a review.

Study uses face-processing (a social task) and likely fMRI, but abstract only mentions adults with Asperger syndrome and does not state inclusion of a healthy control group. Insufficient information about presence/age of healthy participants; include for full-text review to verify eligibility.

Functional MRI was used while participants performed a social task (learning others' trustworthiness/mentalizing). The sample includes healthy younger and older adults, implying at least one group is within the 17–65 range. This is an original fMRI study, not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

The study used only forensic inpatient participants (psychotic offenders and nonpsychotic offenders) and does not include a group of healthy adults. Inclusion requires at least one healthy participant group (age 17–65), so it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

Study used resting-state fMRI (no task) in healthy males to examine oxytocin effects on connectivity. Does not involve an fMRI social-related task or social processing, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

The sample comprises children and adolescents (developmental sample) with no indication of a healthy adult group aged 17–65. Thus it does not meet the age-based inclusion criterion for adult participants.

fMRI study using a mentalizing task (social cognition: understanding self/other) with adult participants; includes a healthy control group of adults (age-matched Controls). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract describes an fMRI study using social cognitive tasks and reports activity in social cognition networks in patients and their unaffected siblings. Unaffected siblings serve as a healthy participant group likely within adult age range; therefore meets inclusion. Abstract lacks explicit ages, so include for full-text review to confirm details.

This record is a protocol for a systematic review and meta-analysis, not a primary fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. It therefore meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

Participants are children (Korean children with ASD and typically developing children), not healthy adults aged 17–65. Although fMRI and social/pragmatic language tasks are used, the sample does not include healthy adult participants meeting the review age criterion.

fMRI study probing social processes (mimicry modulated by emotions and group membership) in human participants; directly relevant to social cognition. Abstract does not specify participant ages/health status, so cannot fully confirm age range/healthy-only criterion—per guidance, include for full-text review.

Abstract reports fMRI during social cognition tasks (fear recognition, gaze processing, theory of mind) in healthy adult men (within 17–65). Behavioral and neural measures of social processing are central. Not a review/meta-analysis. Satisfies inclusion criteria.

Narrative comparative review of face perception across species that summarizes behavioral and fMRI findings; not an original fMRI study conducting social-related tasks in healthy adult human participants. Does not meet inclusion criteria for primary human fMRI studies.

The study used resting-state fMRI connectivity rather than a task-based fMRI scan during a social-related task, so it does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring participants to perform a social task during scanning.

fMRI study examining social cognition (perception of cooperative behavior/theory of mind) with a healthy control group (19 matched controls). Task is social-related; not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of affiliative (social) processing using kinship-related social scenarios in humans; not a review/meta-analysis; appears to involve healthy adult participants. Meets the review objective and inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.
The article is a meta-analysis of fMRI studies rather than an original fMRI study; the exclusion criteria explicitly exclude systematic reviews or meta-analyses.

Title indicates a multilevel kernel density fMRI analysis (a meta-analytic approach) rather than a primary fMRI study with participants performing a social task. Exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses is met.

Abstract describes an fMRI gaze-contingent study of joint attention (a social process) but focuses on adolescents with autism. It does not clearly state inclusion of a healthy adult group aged 17–65. Because the abstract lacks necessary participant-age and control-group detail, include for full-text review to verify presence of eligible healthy adult participants and ages.

Event-related fMRI using the false belief paradigm investigates understanding others' mental states (Perception and Understanding of Others). Appears to involve healthy adult subjects and meets inclusion (social-related fMRI task). Not a review. Include for full-text extraction.
Participants are preadolescents (age 11); meta-analysis requires healthy adult participants aged 17–65. Although fMRI social task is present, the sample age clearly falls outside inclusion criteria.

fMRI study in human adults examining self-, friend-, and unfamiliar-person face and name recognition (perception/understanding of self/others), fitting social-processing constructs. Appears to involve healthy adult participants and is an original experimental study, not a review. Abstract provides sufficient evidence for inclusion.

Participants were domestic dogs, not human adults. The review requires functional MRI studies with human participants (ages 17–65). Although it uses fMRI for social-related face perception, the non-human sample clearly excludes it.

fMRI was used while adult participants (healthy control group and ASD group) viewed dynamic emotional facial expressions, a social perception/understanding-of-others task. Includes healthy adults (controls). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract does not report any fMRI/functional neuroimaging or an fMRI task; it investigates genetic-environment interactions and response inhibition in adolescents. It does not describe a social-related fMRI task or healthy adult participants (17–65). Based on the abstract alone, it does not meet the review’s fMRI/social-processing and population criteria.

fMRI study examining neural responses to learned social roles using a social interaction (cyber-ball) and face-perception task—addresses social processing in humans. Participants appear to be healthy adults; study is empirical (not a review). Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI study in young healthy participants performing an incentive delay task with social rewards; investigates neural correlates of social reward anticipation and feedback (social-related processing). Meets inclusion: functional MRI during a social-related task in healthy adults (likely within 17–65). Not a review.

fMRI study with 20 healthy adult participants examining co-speech gestures and semantic processing—addresses social communication (social-related processing). Not a review/meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria for the review.

Abstract does not describe any social-related task during fMRI; it reports network/semi-metric analysis related to familial risk for psychotic disorder. While controls may be present, there is no evidence of task-based social processing in healthy adults, so it does not meet the review inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of emotion recognition (social cognition) including a healthy control group. Abstract does not report participant ages (17–65 criterion unclear), so include for full-text review to confirm age and details.

This study examines VLPFC connectivity and memory retrieval using fMRI and diffusion imaging; it investigates memory-related networks and anatomical connectivity rather than social-related processing or social tasks. Does not meet the review’s inclusion criterion of social-related tasks.

Study used near-infrared spectroscopy (NIRS) rather than functional MRI. Although it examines social interaction in healthy adults, it does not meet the requirement of an fMRI scan during a social task.

Abstract does not state that an fMRI was used or that healthy adult control group (age 17–65) were included. Study focuses on autism but provides insufficient methodological detail; therefore include for full-text review to determine whether fMRI social-task data in healthy adults are reported.

Title indicates evaluation of face approachability (a social judgment) and reports brain responses, suggesting fMRI during a social task in healthy adults. However the abstract text and details on imaging modality and participant ages/health are not provided, so include for full-text review to confirm methods and sample.

fMRI study examining charitable donation/altruism and neural substrates of social attachment and aversion—clearly social-related processing. Not a review. Abstract lacks explicit participant age/health details, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adults (17–65).

Abstract reports only schizophrenia outpatients randomized to intervention or placebo; no group of healthy adults is described. Therefore it does not meet the requirement of including at least one healthy participant group (age 17–65).

Abstract reports neural (medial prefrontal) responses to social interaction images, indicating an fMRI social-related task. Likely includes a healthy comparison group (remitted depression study) and adult participants. Methods/ages not fully specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study using a social interaction simulation probing friendship-related processes (affiliation, reward, empathy) in 28 human participants. The task clearly targets social processing. The abstract does not report participant ages or explicitly state health status, so include for full-text review to confirm participants meet the 17–65 healthy adult criterion.

The study reports fMRI during an affective ToM task but participants are 25 chronic depression patients; no healthy control group or healthy participants (age 17–65) are mentioned. Therefore it fails the requirement of including at least one healthy adult group.

fMRI study examining self-conscious emotion/social evaluation using a camera-watching task — a social-related task. The sample includes adults (in addition to children/adolescents) and appears to be healthy participants, meeting inclusion criteria for full-text review.

fMRI study of cross-modal face and voice perception (social communication/perception of others) with 20 participants; appears to involve healthy adults and is not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

Abstract reports a single-case (n=1) fMRI study. Inclusion requires at least one group of healthy participants (implying >1). Because this is a single-subject report, it does not meet the sample/group criterion.

Event-related fMRI study of vocal emotional prosody, which targets social communication/perception of others. Abstract indicates neural decoding of emotions (a social-related process) but does not specify participant health status or ages; insufficient detail to confirm inclusion criteria fully. Include for full-text review to verify participant demographics and health.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants (N=26) performing a social learning task (inferring others' generosity). Directly investigates social cognition processes with task-based fMRI and is not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related processing in healthy adults.

The study used EEG (mu rhythm) rather than functional MRI. Although it examines social processing (emotion recognition) in presumably healthy adults, the meta-analysis specifically requires fMRI studies; the abstract provides no fMRI data, so exclude.

fMRI (BOLD) was used while participants viewed scenes of affiliation, isolation, and nonsocial stimuli and made pleasantness judgments — a social-related task (affiliation/isolation). The study reports data from healthy younger and older adults (no patient groups mentioned) and is empirical (not a review). Although exact ages are not given in the abstract, the presence of a 'younger adults' group implies participants within the 17–65 range. Does not meet any exclusion criteria.

Study used resting-state fMRI to identify biomarkers for autism, not a task-based fMRI of social processing in healthy adults. Does not meet the criterion of an fMRI during a social-related task in healthy participants.

fMRI study with 20 healthy adult participants performing a social-related task (mimicry modulated by direct eye contact). Targets social processing (social communication/perception), uses functional MRI, and is primary research (not a review). Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Participants are adolescents (mean ages 15.8 and 16.2), below the required adult age range (17–65). Although the study uses fMRI with socioaffective cues, it includes no healthy adult group meeting inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining neural correlates of verbal irony and Theory of Mind, a social-cognitive process (perception/understanding of others). Involves human participants and is not a review. Abstract does not explicitly report participant ages or health status, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Resting-state fMRI study (no social task performed) and focuses on ultra-high-risk-for-psychosis subjects rather than a task-based sample of healthy adults; does not meet inclusion criterion of fMRI during a social-related task.

fMRI was performed during a face perception task with emotional/neutral stimuli (a social-related process: perception/understanding of others) and the study includes a healthy control group. Not a review. Age range not specified in abstract, so full-text review recommended to confirm participants fall within 17–65.

Abstract describes intrinsic/background functional connectivity (resting-state-like) analyses in first-episode schizophrenia and healthy controls, without reporting an fMRI social-related task. fMRI study examining neural responses to witnessing an emergency (bystander effect), which is a social-related process (perception/understanding of others and action preparation). The abstract indicates human participants and experimental fMRI task. Participant ages/health not specified in abstract; include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study with healthy 'normal volunteers' performing social-related tasks (emotion identification and causal attribution), addressing perception/understanding of others. Abstract does not report participant ages; include for full-text review to confirm age range and other methodological details.

Abstract reports an fMRI study investigating honesty-related signals and their influence on trust (social cognition/perception of others), fitting the review topic. The abstract does not state participant demographics, but it likely tested healthy adults; include for full-text to confirm participant ages/health status.
This is a narrative review of the neurobiology of social phobia, not an original fMRI study with human participants performing a social task. It meets the exclusion criterion (review), so exclude.

Abstract provides insufficient information to confirm a social-task fMRI in healthy adults. Title suggests adults with autism and connectivity (possibly resting-state) and does not state a healthy control group or task-based social processing. Include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

Participants are early adolescent girls (adolescence), which falls below the required adult age range (17–65). Although the study uses fMRI and a social task, the sample does not meet the age inclusion criterion.
Participants are adolescents aged 11.1–15.5 years with no adult sample within the 17–65 range required by inclusion criteria, so the study fails the age eligibility criterion.

Abstract reports an fMRI study where healthy adult participants made social judgments about people (categorical age estimates and individuating food-preference judgments). The task clearly probes social cognition/perception of others; sample appears to be healthy adults; not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing.

Two fMRI experiments investigating mentalizing/theory-of-mind (social cognition) in human participants; examines neural representations of others' beliefs—a social-related task. Not a review or meta-analysis. Although participant ages are not specified in the abstract, the study clearly meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

Original fMRI study investigating neural responses in the extrastriate body area to images of one’s own versus others’ body parts, addressing self/other perception (social cognition). Involves healthy adult participants and a social-related task (perception/understanding of self and others). Not a review. Sufficiently meets inclusion criteria.

Functional MRI was used while participants performed impression-formation about other people (a social-cognitive task). The study examines perception/understanding of others, involves human participants (healthy adult sample implied), and is an original fMRI experiment—not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study investigating Theory of Mind/social cognition using a naturalistic video task (MASC). It clearly addresses social processing; not a review. Abstract does not report participant demographics or explicitly state healthy adult sample, so include for full-text to confirm participants meet age/health criteria.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of emotional prosody (a social communication process) comparing individuals with ASD to control participants, indicating inclusion of healthy controls. Age range not specified in the abstract, so full text is required to confirm participants fall within 17–65. Include for full-text review to verify ages and additional methodological details.

Original fMRI study assessing social brain function during social decisions from faces (affective judgments). Includes healthy adult participants alongside ASD group; task assesses social cognition/perception. Not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social-related processing in healthy adults.

Participants are children (ASD and typically developing children) rather than healthy adults aged 17–65 required by the review. Although it uses fMRI during a social face-processing task, the age criterion is not met; not a review/meta-analysis.

fMRI study with 30 healthy adult participants performing communicative (social communication) versus descriptive speech tasks; investigates neural correlates of social communication, theory-of-mind and social processing in L2. Meets inclusion: fMRI during social-related task, healthy adults (17–65), not a review.

Abstract does not state whether an fMRI was performed or whether healthy adult participants (age 17–65) were included; it focuses on autism and reward but provides insufficient methodological/participant details. Include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

Abstract assesses facial emotion processing (a social cognition task) and includes healthy subjects. While it mentions neurofunctional measures, it does not explicitly state use of fMRI or participant ages. Insufficient detail in the abstract to confirm fMRI and age criteria — include for full-text review to verify imaging modality and age range.

fMRI study in healthy adults examining decisions to share articles and neural activity in self-related, valuation, and perspective-taking regions; task involves social processes (sharing, considering others). Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient evidence to include.

Abstract reports fMRI measurement of amygdala responsiveness during social phobia–related word processing (a social-related task) and includes a matched healthy control group (110 controls) alongside 110 patients; participants are adults. Therefore it meets the inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study investigating implicit personal space (affiliation) with social vs non-social stimuli and reported neural activation; meets the review’s social-processing and fMRI requirements. Participant health/ages aren’t specified in the abstract, so full-text review is warranted to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants reading narratives that probe protected values—a social-cognition task (perception/understanding of others/values). Meets inclusion of fMRI social-related processing in healthy adults; not a review. Age implied adult; full-text can confirm ages if needed.

fMRI experiment with healthy human participants examining mirror-system responses during action observation/execution after sensorimotor training—addresses perception/understanding of others (action understanding), fits the review objective and inclusion criteria; not a review.

This is a conceptual/primer paper about brain-imaging principles, not an empirical fMRI study. The abstract describes theory and recommendations, with no fMRI methods, tasks, or healthy adult participant data—thus it does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring an fMRI scan during a social-related task.

This article is a review summarizing MRI (including fMRI) findings in autism rather than an original fMRI study in healthy adults. It is a review article, which meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

fMRI study on healthy adult practitioners using Compassion-meditation and Reappraisal while viewing people in distress; addresses social processing (affiliation/understanding others) and reports neural responses. Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text review.

fMRI study of social decision-making (one-shot prisoner's dilemma) examining neural correlates of cooperation/defection and social cognition regions in human participants. Abstract does not indicate a clinical sample; task is clearly social. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.

Participants were two young children with autism spectrum disorder (not healthy adults). Although fMRI during social stimuli was used, the study does not include a healthy adult (age 17–65) group required for inclusion in this review.

Functional MRI study measuring neural responses to biological vs scrambled motion (social perception/social communication) in human participants; task is social-related and aligns with review objective. No exclusion criteria met. Abstract implies healthy adult sample; full-text can confirm ages if needed.

fMRI study in healthy human participants examining perception of affective vocalisations (social communication/perception of others). Abstract indicates task-related fMRI and neural responses in superior temporal sulcus. Participant age/health not specified; include for full-text review to confirm age range/health status.

fMRI study with 37 healthy adult participants performing a social communication task (feeling addressed); examines neural processing of body orientation and gesture. Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI of social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study examining social attributions (perception/understanding of others) in human participants and reports neural correlates; not a review. Abstract does not specify ages, so include for full-text review to confirm participants meet the 17–65 healthy adult criterion.

The study used fMRI during a social (Cyberball) task and includes a healthy control group. However, participants are described as adolescents and ages are not reported, so it is unclear whether healthy subjects meet the 17–65 age criterion—include for full-text review.

Abstract describes an fMRI study using the ultimatum game (social decision-making), targeting neural networks involved in social interaction. Participant ages are not specified and the study examines developmental changes, so eligibility (age 17–65) cannot be confirmed from the abstract. Include for full-text review to determine participant characteristics and confirm inclusion criteria.

Study reports fMRI in 23 healthy adult participants performing a visually-based social judgment task (evaluating social dominance in faces), directly addressing social processing. Participants are healthy adults and the paper is an original fMRI study (not a review), meeting inclusion criteria for the meta-analysis.

fMRI BOLD responses were measured while healthy adults (n=35) engaged with idiographic negative self-beliefs and used reappraisal/acceptance. The task targets perception/understanding of self, a social-related construct. Participants are healthy and within the adult age range. Not a review article.

fMRI study examining person perception and mentalising—social cognition processes—in humans. Abstract describes an experimental fMRI task linking perceptual and inferential social networks. It likely tested healthy adult participants, but demographics are not specified; include for full-text review to confirm participant ages/health.

fMRI study of valenced self-referential processing (social-related construct: perception/understanding of self) conducted in 20 adult women. Abstract does not report patient groups or age range or explicit health status, so insufficient to rule out inclusion; include for full-text review to confirm healthy adults and age 17–65.

This is a resting-state fMRI study (no task was performed), so it does not meet the inclusion requirement of an fMRI scan conducted while participants performed a social-related task. Therefore it should be excluded.

Abstract is a narrative overview that mentions early fMRI studies of social emotions but gives no methods, participant details, or results. Insufficient information to determine whether it reports primary fMRI data on healthy adults; include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

This is an editorial/introduction to a special issue, not an original empirical fMRI study. The abstract does not report participants, an fMRI task, or fMRI results; it is a commentary/review of methods. Therefore it does not meet the inclusion criterion of an fMRI scan conducted during a social-related task in human participants.

fMRI study using emotional face/voice classification—a social perception/communication task relevant to social cognition. Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages, so eligibility cannot be confirmed from abstract alone. Include for full-text review to verify healthy adult sample and age range.

Although this is an fMRI study of social processing, all participants (including healthy controls) are children aged 7–13. The review requires healthy adult participants aged 17–65, so the study does not meet the age criterion.

Primary fMRI study examining neural responses to social expectancy violations (perception/understanding of others). Uses human participants in a social task; not a review. Likely healthy adult sample. Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining self- and other-referential recollection (social cognitive processing) in human participants; reports neural activations (mPFC) during social self/other tasks. Appears to involve healthy adult participants and is not a review/meta-analysis.

fMRI study investigating perception of social cues (fearful gaze) — a social-processing task — and includes a matched healthy adult control group (26 adults). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract gives sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.

This is a structural MRI study (manual volumetric tracing of fusiform gyrus) in 22q11.2 deletion syndrome and controls. No fMRI data or task-based social processing paradigm is reported; thus it does not meet the inclusion requirement of an fMRI study of social-related processing in healthy adults.

Participants are children (ASD and typically developing), not healthy adults aged 17–65 as required by the review. Although a TD group is present, the age range falls outside the inclusion criterion, so the study is not eligible.

This appears to be a review article (published in 'Sexual Medicine Reviews') summarizing fMRI studies of female sexual desire/HSDD rather than reporting an original fMRI experiment. It does not describe a social-related task or primary data in healthy adults. Therefore it meets the exclusion criterion for reviews.

Original fMRI study with healthy participants investigating social cognition (third-party punishment, mentalizing, evaluation of others’ responsibility), meeting the review’s social-related task criterion; not a review or meta-analysis.

Study uses fMRI to examine facial emotion processing (a social cognition task). Abstract does not clearly state whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Insufficient information to confirm inclusion/exclusion, so include for full-text review to verify presence of healthy adult participants and relevant task details.

fMRI study investigating theory-of-mind/social exchange processing, which matches the review objective of social-related neural processing. Abstract does not state participant ages or explicit healthy status; include for full-text review to confirm sample meets 17–65 healthy adult criteria.

This is a narrative review of mirror neuron dysfunction in ASD, not an original fMRI study. The abstract reports synthesis of fMRI/TMS/EEG evidence and interventions, with no methods or participant details and no healthy adult fMRI task group; it fails inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining attentional orienting to social gaze and arrow cues (social communication/perception of others). Appears to use healthy adult participants; no indication it is a review. Abstract lacks explicit age range, so include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.

Abstract describes an fMRI randomized controlled study in bipolar disorder patients and reports effects on recognition of happy faces, but does not mention inclusion of any healthy control group. Inclusion criterion requires at least one healthy participant group. Information is insufficient from abstract alone, so include for full-text review to verify presence of healthy adults.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of dietary and altruistic (prosocial) choice, with neural decoding of prosocial attributes—this meets the social-related processing domain. The abstract does not specify participant age or health status, so inclusion for full-text review is warranted to confirm healthy adult sample and ages.

The study reports fMRI data collected in a chronic traumatic brain injury population and the abstract does not mention any healthy control group. Inclusion requires at least one group of healthy participants (age 17–65). Therefore it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

fMRI study in human subjects observing an expert demonstrator, investigating motor resonance and mentalizing (perception and understanding of others). Involves healthy adult participant groups (Naïve, Trained, Expert) and social-cognitive processing; not a review.

Participants are adolescent girls tracked from 2nd–8th grades (i.e., below the 17–65 adult range required). Also the task is a risk-taking task rather than a clearly social-processing task. Excluded based on age criterion.

Abstract reports task-based fMRI including explicit 'social' (and emotion) processing in a large Human Connectome Project sample (n=787) of healthy participants. This meets the review’s requirement for social-related fMRI in healthy adults; full text can confirm exact age range and task details.

fMRI study in 30 healthy participants examining gaze (direct vs averted) effects on action control—a social signal processing task relevant to perception/understanding of others. Not a review/meta-analysis. Age range not stated in abstract, so include for full-text to confirm ages and other details.

fMRI study with 30 healthy adult participants performing communicative (social communication) and descriptive speech tasks; examines neural correlates of L2 communication, theory-of-mind and action simulation—clearly a social-related processing task in healthy adults.

fMRI study reporting neural engagement of person-perception and mentalizing networks during tasks manipulating perceived human animacy (social perception). fMRI was used during a social interaction task (virtual ball-tossing measuring inclusion/exclusion). The study includes a healthy control group of adults alongside BPD patients, meeting the criterion of at least one healthy participant group. Not a review or meta-analysis.

Functional MRI was used with healthy adult participants (male and female) to investigate perception of interpersonal spatial relations (facing vs nonfacing bodies), a social-related processing task (perception/understanding of others). Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI was used to measure brain responses to socially relevant auditory stimuli (one vs two people walking), implicating social-affective and interaction-related regions. Abstract lacks explicit participant age/health details, so include for full-text review.

Empirical fMRI study examining mental state decoding ('Reading the Mind in the Eyes')—a social cognition task—in healthy adult participants (native Japanese and white American). Reports neural correlates; not a review. Fits inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports fMRI hemodynamic responses to child stimuli in neural regions associated with social cognition (social processing). Participant health status not specified; insufficient information to confirm healthy adult group, so include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

The article is an overview/narrative review of molecular neuroimaging studies rather than an original fMRI investigation of social tasks in healthy adults. It thus meets the exclusion criterion for review articles and does not report primary fMRI data for inclusion.

fMRI was performed while participants engaged in a social approval task (social reward processing). The study includes a healthy control group (15 adults) alongside a schizophrenia group. It is an original empirical fMRI study, not a review. Therefore it meets inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI performed during speech repetition could relate to social communication, but abstract does not clearly describe a social-related task or social stimuli. Includes healthy participants. Insufficient information to determine social processing—include for full-text review.

Human fMRI study examining mirror-system responses to action sounds and semantic processing—addresses perception/understanding of others. Abstract does not state participant health status or ages, so inclusion requires full-text to confirm healthy adult sample (17–65).

fMRI 'empathy for pain' task assesses social/affective processing (empathic responses). Study includes both autistic and control (healthy) participants, presumably adult sample, and is an original fMRI study (not a review). Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Participants are patients with mild TBI and cognitive impairment; no healthy adult group is reported. The task (playing piano/music rehabilitation) is not a social-processing task. Does not meet inclusion criteria.

This is a review article ('We review...') summarizing fMRI findings from human and macaque infants and proposing mechanisms; it is not an original fMRI study of social processing in healthy adults. Exclude per exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants (implicit from journal/context) investigating memory for neutral faces in goal-relevant vs goal-irrelevant situations; task involves social stimuli (face identity recognition) and reports activation in social-processing region (superior temporal sulcus), matching social-related processing constructs.

This is a theoretical/review paper discussing explanations of mirror-touch synesthesia and referring to fMRI evidence, but it does not report an original fMRI study with human participants performing a social-related task. Not a primary empirical fMRI study meeting inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports neural correlates of perceiving social interactions in the human brain (pSTS), indicating an fMRI study of social perception in humans. fMRI study examining gaze-direction effects on face processing (social perception/understanding of others). Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages, so eligibility cannot be confirmed from abstract alone; include for full-text review to verify healthy adult (17–65) sample.

Although the study used fMRI on a moral/social task, all participants were children (one HFA, one Asperger’s, three normal children). The review requires at least one group of healthy adults aged 17–65; no healthy adult participants are present.

This study used structural MRI covariance analysis rather than task-based functional MRI (fMRI). It does not report fMRI during social-related tasks, so it fails the inclusion criterion requiring fMRI scanning during a social task.

Abstract describes an fMRI study of prosodic (social communication) processing in autism but does not specify participant groups or ages. Unable to confirm presence of healthy adult (17–65) group from abstract alone — include for full-text review.

fMRI study of theory-of-mind (social cognition) directly involving social-related processing and includes a healthy control group. Abstract does not report participant ages; include for full-text review to confirm that healthy participants fall within 17–65 and to extract details.

fMRI study of social cognition (eye gaze, face processing) that includes neurotypical control group. Abstract lacks participant ages; include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult (17–65) sample and extract data.

Abstract reports two independent fMRI experiments in humans assessing emotional egocentricity bias (social cognition/empathy). Healthy adult participants are implied; task is social-related. Not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

Abstract states this article summarizes psychopharmacological and fMRI research (a review), not reporting original fMRI data from a human participant sample. Abstract discusses brain imaging of ToM and empathy in schizophrenia but does not state whether fMRI was conducted during social tasks or whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Insufficient information to determine eligibility from abstract alone; include for full-text review.

fMRI study measuring neural activation during a social cognition task (judging trustworthiness of faces) and includes a healthy control group. Not a review/meta-analysis. Although participant ages are not stated in the abstract, the sample appears to be adult; meets inclusion criteria for full data extraction.

fMRI study probing social cognition (action observation/execution, action understanding, theory of mind) that included a healthy control group (n=18). Abstract meets criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults; full text can confirm exact ages (17–65) if needed.

fMRI study where participants viewed and recognized actions, probing neural representations in pSTS/MT/MST/EBA—directly relevant to Perception and Understanding of Others. Empirical study with presumed healthy adults; age/health details not reported, so include for full-text review.

The study investigates executive dysfunction and control-network hub modulation in autism, not social-related processing. Although it may include healthy controls, the task is executive, not social; does not meet the review objective of fMRI studies of social processing in healthy adults.

Study used resting-state fMRI and correlated Theory of Mind scores with connectivity; no task-based social processing was performed during the scan. Inclusion requires fMRI during a social-related task, so it does not meet the criterion despite having healthy controls.

fMRI study of audiovisual speech integration (social communication/perception), includes an age- and gender-matched healthy control group, and involves task-based fMRI in humans. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study measuring neural representations of others' mental states (social cognition) in male and female human participants; uses social-brain network measures (mPFC, precuneus). Study involves healthy adult participants and is original research (not a review), meeting inclusion criteria.

The study used simultaneous fMRI (with PET) to probe mothers’ neural responses to their infants—an affiliation/attachment social task—in a sample of adult mothers (healthy adults). Abstract reports an original dyadic fMRI (dfMRI) experiment examining face-to-face social interaction and BOLD responses, identifying empathy/mentalization/default-mode networks—meets fMRI social-processing criterion. fMRI study of social exclusion (social interaction/mentalizing) in healthy participants; not a review. Age described as "male adolescents" but exact ages not provided, so include for full-text review to confirm participants fall within 17–65.

Study reports task-based fMRI in 22 healthy adult males (within 17–65 range) performing social-related judgments (allocentric social hierarchies, social alliance), directly addressing social processing in healthy adults. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full review.

Abstract describes fMRI of self- and other-reflection (a social-processing task) but focuses on schizophrenia; it does not specify whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Insufficient information in abstract to confirm inclusion, so include for full-text review to verify presence of healthy participants.

Abstract describes a field overview/commentary on social neuroscience rather than an original empirical fMRI study. It provides no methods, participant sample, or task-based fMRI data and thus meets the exclusion criterion for reviews.

Participants are described as 'youth' (child/adolescent) and study published in a child psychology journal; no healthy adult (age 17–65) group is reported, so it fails the age-based inclusion criterion for the review.

Abstract describes coherence spectral-density analysis of cerebral activity recorded simultaneously in pairs (likely electrophysiological measures such as MEG/EEG) and makes no mention of functional MRI. Does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring an fMRI scan.

The study used resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based social-processing paradigm. Inclusion requires fMRI during a social-related task; although healthy controls and behavioral social cognition measures are present, the imaging does not meet the task-based criterion.

fMRI was used while participants performed a social interaction task (reaction-time competition with opponents involving provocation and punishment). Resting-state fMRI study in young children (ages 3–7) including an ASD group and matched controls; not a task-based social-processing fMRI study and does not include healthy adult participants (17–65).

Primary research using fMRI during a charitable-giving task probing social processes (empathy, perspective taking, attention). fMRI study with healthy adult participants examining affective creativity via reappraisal of anger-evoking events. Abstract lacks explicit detail that task probes social interaction, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

The study examines memory control and functional connectivity during a recognition task, not social-related processing. Although it uses fMRI in healthy adults, the task does not involve social constructs (affiliation, communication, self/other perception). Not a review article.

fMRI was performed showing activation (right middle frontal cortex) while participants evaluated 'self' vs 'non-self' MHC peptides in body odour—a social-related task involving perception/understanding of self and mate-evaluation in healthy volunteers. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining perception of emotions and interactions in dynamic crowds—clearly a social-processing task. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not specify participant demographics/health, so include for full-text review to confirm sample meets healthy adult (17–65) criterion.

The article is explicitly a review summarizing the authors' research program rather than a primary fMRI study. It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses, so it should be excluded despite relevance to social perception.

This is a narrative/review of ecstatic and related epileptic phenomena using neuroimaging; it does not report an fMRI experiment with healthy adult participants performing a social-related task. Appears to focus on patient cases, not primary fMRI social-processing data.

fMRI study where participants watched dynamic faces and attended to facial aspects (emotional valence, age), addressing perception/understanding of others. Participants are children (mean age ~10.1 years), which falls outside the required age range of 17–65 for inclusion. Study otherwise uses fMRI and social tasks but fails the age criterion.

fMRI study with human participants performing a social task (judgments of faces after cooperative/defective play in a Prisoner’s Dilemma), investigates social cognition (moral status, fairness). Resting-state fMRI study in a sample of Major Depressive Disorder patients (no healthy control group reported) and no task-based social processing paradigm. Does not meet inclusion criteria requiring task-based fMRI involving social processing and at least one healthy participant group (age 17–65).

fMRI study using the Prisoner’s Dilemma (a social interaction task) measuring neural responses to cooperation/non-cooperation in healthy adult men and women. Meets inclusion criteria (task-based fMRI in healthy adults) and is not a review. Abstract provides sufficient detail to include for full-text review.

Abstract reports original fMRI research (mega-analysis of four fMRI studies) in which participants considered others' mental states — a social cognition task. It therefore meets the requirement of fMRI during social-related processing in (presumably) healthy adult participants. Not a systematic review/meta-analysis.

Study used functional MRI while participants observed human and robot agents experiencing pain/pleasure (an empathy/social cognition task). Sample comprises healthy adult participants (n=26). Not a review/meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social-related processing in healthy adults.

Primary fMRI study using a social ‘social-norm inference’ audio-visual task assessing judgments about others’ reactions. Includes a healthy control group (typical development adults) alongside HFA participants. Not a review/meta-analysis and meets the social-processing and fMRI inclusion criteria.

fMRI experiment (N=31) examined neural responses to disfigured faces, which tests social perception/understanding of others and social cognition (empathy). The study appears to involve healthy adults but the abstract does not explicitly state participant health status or ages; include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Study used resting-state/structural MRI (no task-based social fMRI) and participants are boys with mean ages ~11–12 (age ranges 5.5–19.7), not healthy adults aged 17–65. Fails task requirement and age criterion.

fMRI study with congenitally blind and sighted participants performing identity and emotion recognition from voices—clearly social perception (perception of others). Includes healthy participants and is not a review. Abstract lacks explicit ages, so full text may be checked, but sufficient evidence to include for full-text review.

fMRI study with healthy non-clinical sample of young adult males (age within 17–65) performing social-related tasks (empathic processing of social interaction scenarios). Not a review; meets inclusion criteria.

The article is explicitly a review ('In this review...') rather than an original fMRI study. Exclusion criterion disallows systematic reviews or meta-analyses; abstract provides no primary fMRI data on healthy adults performing social tasks.

fMRI was conducted during an emotional task and the study includes a healthy control group (n=25, likely adults). The abstract does not clearly state whether the task is explicitly social-related, so inclusion for full-text review is warranted to confirm relevance to social processing.

The study reports event-related fMRI collected while participants performed a mind-perception task (social-cognitive processing) and links neural activity to social attention performance. It is an original empirical fMRI study (not a review) and appears to involve healthy adult participants, meeting the review inclusion criteria.

The study uses resting-state fMRI (no task); inclusion requires task-based fMRI during social-related processing. Abstract does not describe participants performing any social task, so it should be excluded.

Abstract reports an fMRI study with pupillometry examining pupil-mimicry effects on trust and recruitment of theory-of-mind network—clearly a social-related task (perception/understanding of others, affiliation). Study appears to involve human participants (likely healthy adults) and is an original empirical fMRI study, not a review. Sufficient information to include for full-text review to confirm participant ages/health.

fMRI study using social scenarios examining emotional responses to risky decisions; includes healthy young adult participants (young adults and late adolescents) performing a social-related task. Meets inclusion criteria for social processing in healthy adults; no exclusion criteria met.

Block-design fMRI study of perception of facial expressions (social communication/perception of others), measuring neural responses in face-selective regions. This fits the review objective of fMRI studies of social processing. Participant health/age not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Study used BOLD fMRI (3T) during processing of humorous cartoons, framed as social cognition, in 29 healthy subjects. This fits the review objective of social-related fMRI in healthy adults. Age range not reported—include for full-text review to confirm ages and details.

Study is an RCT protocol for a behavioral intervention in individuals with psychotic disorder; abstract contains no fMRI methods or social-task neuroimaging and does not focus on healthy adult participants.

fMRI was conducted while healthy adult participants retrieved biographical/person knowledge (social processing). The task involves perception/understanding of others (social knowledge retrieval). Not a review; meets inclusion criteria.

Participants were recruited while entering psychotherapy for depression and/or anxiety; the abstract does not report any healthy adult comparison group. Thus it fails the inclusion criterion requiring at least one healthy participant group (age 17–65).

Event-related fMRI study in humans investigating processing of angry voice prosody (social communication/social cognition). Participants performed a social-related task (attending to voices); likely healthy adult sample; not a review or meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI studies of social processing.

Functional MRI study of social communication (communicative intentions). Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages (17–65). Insufficient detail to confirm eligibility, so include for full-text review to verify healthy adult sample and age range.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of social cognition (learning to simulate others’ decisions) using behavioral, modeling, and fMRI methods. Participant health/ages not specified in abstract, so include for full-text confirmation.

Task-based fMRI investigating interpersonal trust/distrust (social-attitude control) in healthy adult participants (n=60). Study targets social cognition/perception of others and reports neural activity during task; not a review. Abstract provides sufficient detail to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of Theory of Mind (social cognition) performed during task-based scanning; includes a healthy adult control group (25 age- and gender-matched controls). Fits inclusion criteria (social-related task; healthy participants 17–65). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text review.

The study reports resting-state functional connectivity in cocaine-dependent individuals and examines delay discounting and reversal learning (cognitive control), not social-related processing. It does not describe a social task or a healthy adult group performing social processing during fMRI.

Abstract reports fMRI during social-distance trials (photographs of participants' friends vs acquaintances), indicating a social-processing task in humans. Not a review. Participant health and ages not specified in the abstract, so include for full-text confirmation of healthy adult sample and age range.

fMRI study of gesture-speech integration (social communication) including healthy adult control groups (n=19, n=17). Task involves social-related processing and is not a review.
