Although ages not specified, participants are described as adult healthy controls; sufficient for inclusion for full-text review.

fMRI study using the Trust Game (social decision-making) examining neural correlates of Machiavellian traits. This addresses social-related processing in an apparent healthy adult sample; not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient detail for inclusion; full text can confirm ages and health if needed.

Primary fMRI study with healthy adult participants performing social-related task (implicit/explicit emotional facial expression processing—social communication/perception of others). Not a review/meta-analysis; meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study using a Theory of Mind (social) task relevant to social processing. Includes a matched control group of presumably healthy participants alongside high-risk relatives. Abstract is not explicit about participant ages (17–65), so include for full-text review to confirm demographics and details.

Study used event-related fMRI (with simultaneous EEG) in 14 healthy adults (mean age 29±6) while they viewed and evaluated others' emotional facial expressions—an explicit social processing task (perception/understanding of others/empathy). Participants are within the 17–65 age range and this is an original empirical study, not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of observation and mental imagery of face and limb movements addressing limb gesture processing and social communication—fits social-processing domain. Abstract does not state participant demographics/ages; include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample (17–65).

Study uses fMRI to measure neural responses to viewing/listening to another person’s non-verbal facial and vocal behaviors—fits 'Perception and Understanding of Others' social processing. Abstract does not state participant health status or ages; because inclusion requires at least one healthy adult group and this is unclear from the abstract, include for full-text review to verify sample eligibility.

Functional MRI was used while participants processed emotional facial expressions (a social-related task). The study includes a healthy control group (mean age 27, within 17–65). Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

Human fMRI study examining how learning another person's values alters value representations in mPFC and behavior—clearly a social-learning task relevant to perception/understanding of others. Abstract implies healthy adult human participants (typical for this journal), though ages/health not explicitly stated; include for full-text review to confirm participant demographics.

fMRI study examining social communication/vitality forms in speech and actions; tasks require processing social aspects (speech prosody, action expression). Human participants (adult participants implied) scanned with fMRI. Not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Study reports task-based fMRI analysis including a social cognition task (explicitly listed among task domains). Abstract indicates whole-brain task-modulated connectivity during tasks, meeting the review objective of social-related processing. Participant details (healthy adult status and ages 17–65) are not specified in the abstract, so full-text review is needed to confirm sample criteria.

fMRI study examining direct and reflected self-appraisals (social-related processing). Includes a healthy adult group aged 23–30 (within 17–65). Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study includes a theory-of-mind (social attribution of belief) task probing social cognition. Participants scanned with fMRI; likely healthy adults though ages not specified in abstract. No exclusion criteria met. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.

fMRI study investigating implicit false-belief (theory of mind) processing—clearly a social-cognitive task involving perception/understanding of others. Not a review. Abstract does not state participant ages, but likely healthy adults; include for full-text to confirm eligibility.

Study used fMRI during a social exclusion (interactive ball-toss) task probing social processing in humans; reports neural responses and individual differences. Participants appear to be healthy adults. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social-task in healthy adults; not a review/meta-analysis.

Original fMRI study in healthy adult humans examining effort production during collaborative vs competitive (social) contexts; addresses social cognition/motivation and uses functional MRI. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria.

The article is a meta-analysis (activation likelihood estimation of 125 fMRI studies), and thus meets the exclusion criterion 'systematic reviews or meta-analyses.' The abstract indicates no new primary participant data. Exclude based on abstract alone.

fMRI performed in healthy adult women (ages 25–50) during viewing of erotic pictures/videos, which taps perception of others and sexual/affiliative responses (social-affective processing). Meets inclusion (social-related task in healthy adults); not a review/meta-analysis. Include for full-text review.
This article is a meta-analysis/systematic review of fMRI studies rather than an original fMRI study with human participants; excluded per the exclusion criterion.
This is a resting-state fMRI parcellation study, not a task-based fMRI of social processing. No social-related task or measures are reported in the abstract, so it is irrelevant.

Functional MRI was performed during an explicit emotion-recognition task (social perception/understanding of others) in a sample of healthy young adult males (within 17–65). The study examines neural responses (amygdala) to social/emotional stimuli and is not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study using a social appraisal task (liking emotional faces) with a healthy control group (n=21) and patient group. Task targets social processing/perception of others. Not a review. Abstract doesn’t state exact ages but participants are adults; meets inclusion—include for full-text review if age needs confirmation.

fMRI study of abstract vs concrete mindsets framed within social cognition. Participants performed why/how and category/exemplar tasks, but abstract does not clearly state use of explicit social stimuli or social-processing tasks. Information is insufficient to determine exclusion, so include for full-text review to confirm applicability to social-related processing.

Abstract reports an fMRI experiment investigating social-cognitive processes (imitation control, self–other distinction, mental state attribution), matching the review’s social-related processing objective. It is not a review/meta-analysis. Participant health status and ages are not specified in the abstract, so full-text review is needed to confirm inclusion criteria (healthy adults 17–65).

Abstract reports human participants performing cooperative/competitive tasks with neural tracking in frontal regions (area 9, ACC), indicating fMRI measurement of social-related processing in healthy adults. No exclusion criteria met and sufficient info to include for full-text data extraction.

Original fMRI study with 37 healthy adult participants viewing social-evaluative videos (social communication/perception of others). Task clearly assesses social-related processing; participants are healthy adults. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text review and data extraction.

fMRI hyperscanning study of mutual gaze and joint attention—clearly social-processing tasks. Involves human participant pairs (presumably healthy adults) and is an original empirical study, not a review. Abstract does not contradict inclusion criteria; include for full-text review to confirm ages and health status if needed.

This is a review article summarizing neuroimaging literature on face processing in ASD, not a primary fMRI study. The abstract describes no original fMRI methods, participants, or data from healthy adults (17–65). Therefore it does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring an fMRI scan conducted with human participants performing a social-related task.

Study reports an fMRI experiment where participants attributed awareness to a cartoon face (a social attribution task related to perception/understanding of others). It involves healthy human subjects and is not a review. Fits inclusion criteria; include for full-text review to confirm participant ages (17–65) if needed.

fMRI study in adult mothers exposing them to infant cries (social/attachment-related task). Participants are human adults (likely healthy mothers) within target age range; task probes affiliation/attachment and social processing. Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text data extraction.
Study used resting-state fMRI (no social-related task during scanning). Inclusion requires fMRI during a social-related task; therefore exclude despite presence of healthy controls.

fMRI task involved active listening to human footsteps and reports engagement of the 'social cognition' posterior STS, indicating social-related processing (perception of others). Abstract does not specify participant ages/health, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants performing a social-related task (viewing/assessing social groups; perception/understanding of others). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient info to meet inclusion criteria for full-text data extraction.

This is an fMRI study of emotional speech prosody (social communication) in human participants performing explicit and implicit social-related tasks. It reports data from 22 subjects (presumably healthy adults) and is an original research article, not a review. Fits the review objective; include for full-text screening to confirm participant ages/health.

fMRI study with healthy participants viewing a moral dilemma about kin vs non-kin; investigates social-cognitive processes (moral conflict, mentalizing, decision making) relevant to social relatedness. Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study in healthy young adults performing tasks that include peer observation and social-cognitive processing (peer influence, social cognition). Participants are within the target age range and healthy; not a review. The abstract indicates social-related processing during task-based fMRI, meeting inclusion criteria.
This is a resting-state fMRI connectivity study (no task was performed during scanning). Inclusion requires task-based fMRI of social-related processing; therefore it does not meet the criterion.

Abstract lacks key details: no explicit mention of fMRI scanning or presence of a healthy control group. The topic (visual personal familiarity) could involve social processing, but information is insufficient to determine eligibility. Include for full-text review to confirm imaging modality and participant groups.

fMRI was used while participants performed social cognition tasks (reasoning about others’ mental states). Participants are described as neurologically normal (healthy). No exclusion criteria met. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participants fall within 17–65.

All participants were non-treatment-seeking individuals with alcohol use disorder (n=15); no healthy control group is reported. Inclusion requires at least one healthy participant group aged 17–65, so the study does not meet inclusion criteria.

This is a review/chapter summarizing amygdala findings across neurodevelopmental and neuropsychiatric disorders, not an original fMRI experiment. It does not report fMRI data from healthy adult participants performing social-related tasks; therefore it meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews.

Functional MRI was used while participants made self- and friend-related social judgments (self/other trait and memory), directly addressing social cognitive processing (self/other). The study reports original fMRI data in healthy participants (adult sample implied) and is not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social-processing studies; include for full-text review.

This is a conceptual/review article discussing relationships between emotion perception and theory of mind and synthesizing lesion and fMRI findings, not an original fMRI study. The abstract indicates it is a review rather than reporting a functional MRI experiment in healthy adults, meeting the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of emotional prosody comprehension (social communication/perception of others). It addresses social processing in adults. Participant details (health/age) are not specified in the abstract; include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

fMRI study in healthy adults where participants received interpersonal manual touch by other people (a social-touch paradigm). This probes social-related processing (social interaction/perception of others) during scanning. Participants are healthy adults within the target age range and the study is empirical (not a review). Therefore it meets inclusion criteria based on the abstract.

Study used resting-state fMRI in toddlers with autism and an eye-tracking–identified ASD subtype, not a task-based social processing fMRI in healthy adults. Participants are young children with ASD (not healthy 17–65 adults), so it does not meet the review inclusion criteria.

fMRI study probing social cognition (responses to emotionally salient human eyes/mentalizing). Abstract indicates comparison between Tourette patients and healthy controls (adults), meeting requirement for a healthy adult group (likely age 17–65). Not a review/meta-analysis.

This article is a quantitative meta-analysis (combining data from 22 fMRI and 2 PET studies) rather than a primary fMRI study. Exclusion criteria explicitly remove systematic reviews or meta-analyses, so it should be excluded despite its relevance to social processing.

FMRI study using a social task (Trust Game) investigating social perspective-taking in healthy participants. Abstract does not report participant ages; adolescents likely include minors, so age eligibility (≥17) is unclear. Include for full-text review to confirm participant age range and full eligibility.

This is a review/book chapter discussing developmental social neuroscience and adolescent social influence, not an original fMRI study. The abstract provides no fMRI methods, participant details, or adult (17–65) healthy sample. It therefore does not meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports changes in brain activation and connectivity linked to compassion training and altruistic responses to others’ suffering in healthy adults, implying an fMRI task probing social cognition/perception of others. Fits inclusion (social-related processing, healthy adult sample) and is not a review.

No functional MRI was conducted; the study reports focus group and questionnaire data from teenage students (adolescents), not an fMRI task in healthy adults (17–65). Does not meet inclusion criteria.

The fMRI study investigates nonconscious memory and emotional valence using a recognition memory task with visual stimuli, not social-related processing (e.g., affiliation, communication, self/other perception). Although participants are healthy adults, the task does not involve social constructs, so it does not meet the review’s inclusion criteria.

The abstract describes an activation likelihood estimation meta-analysis of fMRI studies (a meta-analysis), not original primary fMRI data. The review's exclusion criteria disallow systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

fMRI was conducted while human participants performed a social perception task (categorizing actions; involves mentalizing/motor resonance networks). Not a review. Although participant ages/health not specified in abstract, the study likely uses healthy adults; insufficient detail on age/clinical status means include for full-text verification.

The article is a coordinate-based meta-analysis of fMRI studies (activation likelihood estimation). The exclusion criteria explicitly exclude systematic reviews or meta-analyses, so this study should be excluded.

Study reports fMRI of language/semantic comprehension in patients with schizophrenia; abstract does not describe a social-related task nor mention a healthy adult control group (ages 17–65). Therefore it does not meet inclusion criteria.

Study involves preschool-aged children with autism spectrum disorder, not healthy adults aged 17–65. Abstract does not describe an fMRI social-task in healthy adult participants; therefore it does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study with 21 healthy adult male participants (within 17–65). Task involved perception/understanding of dyadic nonverbal social interactions (social communication/perception of others), meeting the review’s social-related task criterion. Not a review/meta-analysis and no exclusion criteria met based on the abstract.

Healthy adult volunteers underwent fMRI including an experimental task contrasting anticipation of touching an animate (human hand) vs inanimate target—an explicit social-related interaction/perception paradigm. Meets inclusion criteria (task-based fMRI, social processing, healthy participants). Not a review.

Two fMRI experiments examining mentalizing (social cognition) about individuals and groups; task involves perception/understanding of others. Not a review/meta-analysis. Although participant ages/health not specified, context strongly indicates healthy adult sample; meets inclusion.

Study reports fMRI in healthy adults (trustee role in the Trust Game), a clearly social-related task probing reciprocity/social processing. Participants are healthy adults and this is original research (not a review), meeting inclusion criteria.

Participants are children/adolescents (not within the required 17–65 adult range), and the fMRI task examined basic auditory-visual perceptual processing rather than social-related processing; no healthy adult group is present.

fMRI study of perception and understanding of others (processing facial expressions of disgust), a social-cognitive task in humans. Abstract implies healthy adult subjects but does not state ages; include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.

fMRI study using the cyberball social inclusion task (social processing) and includes a healthy control group (17 HC). Participants are adults (clinical groups and HCs) and the task probes social inclusion; not a review. Meets inclusion criteria based on abstract.

The study investigates hypnotic suggestion-induced modulation of pain and sensory processing, not a social-related task or social cognitive construct. The abstract does not describe social interaction, communication, or perception/understanding of self/others, so it does not meet the inclusion criteria for social processing fMRI studies.

Abstract reports fMRI in individuals with PAX6 mutation during verbal fluency and sentence completion, but does not clearly describe a social-related task or the presence of a healthy adult control group. Information is insufficient to determine eligibility for a social-processing meta-analysis, so include for full-text review.

fMRI study of social-related processing (neural responses to outcomes for self, friend, antagonist) in healthy participants. Meets inclusion of social-task fMRI and healthy group. Age range not reported in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm age eligibility.

The study used repetitive transcranial magnetic stimulation (rTMS) to test causal role of right IPL rather than conducting functional MRI during a social task. Inclusion requires an fMRI scan; thus it does not meet the primary inclusion criterion.

fMRI study examining neural and behavioral responses to gaze shifts (social cognition/joint attention) in humans. Abstract indicates a social-related task relevant to social perception. Participant health/ages not specified, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and age range.

Functional MRI study in healthy adult participants examining neural activity when attributing intentions to human- versus computer-generated music, directly assessing mental state attribution/social cognition (aMFC, STS, temporal poles). Fits inclusion criteria (fMRI, social-related task, healthy adults). Not a review.

Empirical fMRI study where participants performed a social-related task (judging social orientation of point-light displays and human-like walkers), probing mirror and mentalizing systems. Fits review objective. Abstract does not explicitly state participant ages or health status, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adult sample and extract details.

fMRI was performed measuring brain response to fearful faces (a social/emotional processing task) in adult males. The study includes a healthy control group matched for IQ/age/education, meeting the requirement of at least one healthy participant group. Therefore it fits the meta-analysis objective.
Participants are children with autism spectrum disorder; no group of healthy adults aged 17–65 is included. Does not meet the review’s requirement of at least one healthy adult participant group.

7T fMRI study conducting a rest-task-rest paradigm where participants listened to attachment-related social narratives (attachment/affiliation processing). Includes healthy adult participants (23 healthy males). This directly assesses social-related processing in healthy adults, meeting inclusion criteria and not a review.

Event-related fMRI study investigating perception of gender from faces—a social perception task (understanding others). Abstract does not state participant health or ages; insufficient detail to confirm sample meets 17–65 healthy criteria. Include for full-text review to verify participant characteristics and confirm eligibility.

fMRI study examining mentalizing, empathy and prosocial behavior (social cognition) in human participants. The task is social-related (mentalizing about similar/dissimilar others) and reports neural activation (dmPFC, vlPFC). Participants appear to be healthy adults; not a review/meta-analysis. Relevant to the review objective—include for full-text review to confirm age range and health status if needed.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants using a social-evaluation task (in-group/out-group politician trait ratings), directly examining social processing and vACC responses. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient detail to meet inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.
Abstract does not specify use of fMRI or whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Because key inclusion information is missing, include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

This paper is an activation likelihood estimation meta-analysis (meta-analysis) of fMRI studies, not a primary fMRI study. It therefore meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

Primary fMRI study of social judgment/perception of others (social processing). Not a review. Abstract does not specify participant ages or explicit healthy sample; per screening rules, include for full-text review to confirm participants meet healthy adult (17–65) criterion.

Abstract reports fMRI activation differences (default mode network) during action-sentence processing in healthy adults; the 'why' (abstract) condition may tap social-cognitive processes (understanding reasons/intentions). The abstract does not clearly state social/affiliation/other-specific tasks, so information is insufficient to determine exclusion. Include for full-text review to confirm whether task meets social processing criteria.

fMRI study employing a dynamic facial-expression localizer and neurofeedback targeting pSTS; task assesses perception of others’ facial expressions (social processing). Conducted in human subjects (reported across subjects) and is not a review. Although ages not specified in abstract, the study fits inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults and warrants inclusion for full-text review.

Abstract reports an fMRI study of empathy for pain and prosocial behavior in (presumably) healthy adult participants, addressing social processing (perception/understanding of others). It is an original empirical study, not a review. Sufficient information in the abstract indicates it meets the review objective and inclusion criteria.

fMRI study using the Trust Game, a social interaction task probing reciprocity and perspective-taking (perception/understanding of others). No indication participants were clinical; meets inclusion of healthy adult social-processing fMRI. Not a review or meta-analysis. Include for full-text data extraction.

fMRI study with 29 healthy adult participants observing others’ actions; task investigates representation of others’ actions/interactions (social cognition: perception/understanding of others). Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of vocal emotion recognition (social processing). Participants are healthy and aged 8–19, which includes ages 17–19 falling within the 17–65 eligibility window; however, it’s unclear whether there is a distinct adult group. Include for full-text review to confirm age-group eligibility and other details.

Study reports fMRI during participants’ judgments about social categories/stereotypes (a social cognition task). Participants are human and presumably healthy adults; task clearly involves perception/understanding of others. Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI studies.

Abstract describes an fMRI social-cognitive task (visual perspective-taking) in ASD and schizophrenia but does not state whether a healthy control group is included. Insufficient participant detail in abstract—include for full-text review to confirm presence of healthy adults (17–65) and fMRI task details.

This study used structural MRI (cortical thickness and structural covariance) in ASD vs controls rather than task-based functional MRI of social processing in healthy adults. No fMRI social-task in healthy 17–65 participants is described, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

Study reports resting-state brain activity in bvFTD patients; no task-based fMRI of social processing is described and abstract does not indicate inclusion of a healthy adult task-performing group (17–65). Therefore it does not meet the requirement for task-based fMRI in healthy adults.

Resting-state fMRI in children (ASD and typically developing), not task-based social processing; participants are children, not healthy adults aged 17–65. Therefore does not meet inclusion criteria for task-based social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI was used during a facial emotion recognition task (a social-processing task) and the study included a neurotypical control group of adults; meets inclusion criteria for social fMRI in healthy adults.

Original fMRI study investigating neural correlates of social interaction (emotion alignment) while pairs of participants rated and communicated emotional arousal. Tasks are clearly social (social communication/influence). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not explicitly state ages/health, but study context implies healthy adult participants; include for full-text review to confirm demographics.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants (omnivores, vegetarians, vegans) performing a social-related task—observation/processing of others’ mouth actions—examining mirror, empathy, and social cognition networks. Fits inclusion criteria (social processing in healthy adults). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information for inclusion.

fMRI study examining neural mechanisms of persuasion/expert influence — a social cognitive process (social influence, trust, evaluation). Abstract reports task-based fMRI linking expert context to brain activity in regions for social valuation and memory. No exclusion criteria met; likely conducted in healthy adults. Recommend full-text inclusion.

Includes an original fMRI experiment comparing social vs. non-social image appraisal (ROI BOLD analyses) in an independent dataset, so it is not solely a meta-analysis. Meets review objective of fMRI studies of social processing. Full text should be checked to confirm participant ages and health, but abstract provides sufficient grounds to include for full-text review.

fMRI study of social feedback addressing social-related processing (inclusion/exclusion). Participants described as a ‘population-derived sample of adolescents’ but ages not specified; unclear whether participants fall within the review’s 17–65 range. Abstract otherwise meets inclusion criteria. Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and health status.

The abstract explicitly states this paper is a review of task-related functional neuroimaging studies in 22q11.2 deletion syndrome rather than original fMRI experiments. It is therefore a systematic review-style article and meets the exclusion criterion; no evidence it reports fMRI data from healthy adults.

Abstract is brief and does not state whether a functional MRI task was used or report participant ages/health status. Title suggests neuroimaging of mentalising including typical development and ASD, so it may include healthy adult controls. Insufficient information to confirm fMRI and age range—include for full-text review.

fMRI study where healthy participants judged social concepts (social semantic processing). Task directly probes social-related processing; meets inclusion. Abstract indicates healthy participants and neural correlates in anterior temporal and medial prefrontal cortex. No exclusion criteria met.

Original fMRI study using dynamic audio-visual emotional stimuli addressing perception of others’ emotions (social cognition). Not a review. Although participant ages/health status not explicitly stated in abstract, the paradigm and objectives strongly indicate healthy adult participants; include for full-text confirmation if needed.

fMRI study modeling neural responses to sentences; analysis includes a factor for social interaction vs physical state, indicating social-processing content. Abstract does not specify participant ages but likely healthy adults; insufficient detail on demographics, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Abstract reports behavioral judgments of ambiguous social interactions following rough/smooth touch and describes associated neural activation (primary/secondary somatosensory cortices, amygdala, hippocampus, inferior prefrontal cortex), indicating neuroimaging during a social task in healthy adults. The abstract does not explicitly state ‘fMRI’ or participant ages, so include for full-text review to confirm imaging modality and participant demographics.

fMRI study where healthy volunteers performed judgments of a self-conscious social emotion (pride) vs basic positive emotion (joy), engaging social cognition/theory-of-mind processes. Sample described as healthy participants; age range not specified in abstract so include for full-text confirmation. Not a review.

This is a review article of functional near-infrared spectroscopy (fNIRS) studies in Autism Spectrum Disorder (children/infants), not an original fMRI study in healthy adults performing social tasks. It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews and does not meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract does not specify that fMRI was used, nor does it report participant ages or that healthy adults (17–65) were included. Although face processing is a social-related construct, the study appears developmental. Insufficient information to determine eligibility from the abstract—include for full-text review.

fMRI study presenting dynamic facial expressions (onset/offset of happy and angry faces) addressing social communication/perception. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not state participant age/health explicitly, so include for full-text review to confirm sample meets healthy adult (17–65) criterion.

fMRI experiment manipulating social competition (a social interaction/processing task) in human participants, meeting review focus. Abstract does not specify participant ages or health status, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adults 17–65.

Event-related fMRI study of self-face recognition (Perception and Understanding of Self) in right-handed healthy subjects, matching the review focus on social-related processing in healthy adults. Abstract does not report participant ages (17–65 criterion unclear), so include for full-text review to confirm age range and other eligibility details.

fMRI study using a socio-emotional preference task examining social preference processing and network interactions, directly addressing social-related processing. Abstract does not state participant ages or explicitly confirm healthy adult sample, so include for full-text review to verify participants meet the 17–65 healthy adult criterion.

fMRI study in which participants (31 healthy controls) performed an agency inference task addressing perception/understanding of self (agency), a social-related construct. Includes a healthy adult group (likely ages 17–65) and is not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study using the Reading the Mind in the Eyes Task (social cognition/perception of others) and includes an age-matched healthy control group (n=28). Participants are adults; study is primary research (not a review). Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study where participants (adults) were scanned while receiving romantic interest/rejection in a speed-dating social task—directly examines social-affective processing. Not a review/meta-analysis and fits inclusion criteria for healthy adult samples; include for full-text review.

Abstract reports an event-related fMRI study examining ACC responses when subjects process outcomes of others' decisions, addressing perception/understanding of others — a social processing task. Participant health/ages are not specified; per instructions, include for full-text review when details are insufficient.

Abstract reads like a narrative review summarizing fMRI studies of deception rather than reporting a single original experiment. It does not clearly state that fMRI scans were conducted on healthy adults performing a social task. Insufficient information to determine eligibility from abstract alone—include for full-text review.

fMRI study of amygdala responses to masked fearful eyes — a social-perception task probing others' emotional cues. Uses healthy volunteers implied by the oxytocin pharmacological design but abstract does not specify participant ages/health. Include for full-text review to confirm age (17–65) and participant health.

fMRI study of facial recognition—a social cognition/perception task—conducted during face-viewing in human participants. Abstract does not state participant ages or explicitly confirm health status; therefore include for full-text review to verify participants meet age (17–65) and healthy criteria.

Abstract reports an fMRI social-cognitive task (neutral facial expressions) in healthy adult participants (n=74) assessing social processing and neural responses. Study is empirical (not a review) and meets inclusion criteria for fMRI of social-related processing in healthy adults.

The study used resting-state fMRI (RSFC) rather than a task-based social processing paradigm. Inclusion requires functional MRI during a social-related task; although healthy controls were included, no task was performed. Therefore it does not meet the inclusion criteria.
Participants are preterm infants (31+6 to 36+3 weeks PMA), not adults 17–65. The fMRI task assessed somatosensory/motor mapping, not social-related processing. Does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining face identity and changeable aspects (expressions/viewpoint) — relevant to Social Communication/Perception of Others. Abstract does not report participant demographics or explicitly confirm healthy adults (17–65), so include for full-text review to verify eligibility.

Abstract describes an fMRI study in borderline personality disorder focusing on anger/aggression but does not state whether a healthy control group was included or whether the task qualifies as social processing. Insufficient information to determine inclusion; include for full-text review.

Study used fMRI while participants completed the Reading-the-Mind-in-the-Eyes Task (a social/affective theory-of-mind task) and included a healthy non-offender control group (H). This meets the meta-analysis objective and inclusion criteria.

This article is a meta-analysis of 33 fMRI studies (systematic review/meta-analysis). The exclusion criteria explicitly exclude systematic reviews or meta-analyses. Although relevant to fMRI of social processing, it is not a primary fMRI study and should be excluded.

fMRI study of empathic accuracy (social processing) conducted in healthy adult participants (n=34). Task involves perception/understanding of others’ emotions; not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient detail to meet inclusion criteria.

The study used fMRI during a social closeness task (photos of friends vs unknown), directly assessing social processing. The abstract does not state participant ages or explicit health status, so full-text review is needed to confirm inclusion criteria (healthy adults aged 17–65). Include for full-text screening.

Double-blind intranasal oxytocin study used fMRI while participants performed an interpersonal space/social task (friend vs stranger). Participants appear to be healthy adults and neural activity during social processing is reported. Not a review; meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI experiment with human participants viewing violent social interactions—task assesses perception/understanding of others (social processing). Not a review/meta-analysis and appears to involve healthy adult observers. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social-related processing.

Study reports resting-state functional connectivity and cerebellar morphometry in adults with ASD, not fMRI during a social-related task. Abstract does not indicate a healthy control group aged 17–65. Thus it fails the task-based and healthy-participant inclusion criteria.

Study 2 used fMRI to measure neural responses in regions linked to mental state attribution while participants viewed social (sexualized vs clothed) targets. Participants are healthy adults (including heterosexual men); the task probes perception/understanding of others. Not a review. Fits inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Participants are children (10–15 years), not within the target adult age range (17–65), and the fMRI task assessed passive auditory change detection, not social-related processing. Thus it does not meet inclusion criteria.

This article is a review of research (narrative review) summarizing studies from 2005–2010, not an original fMRI experiment reporting data. It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses and does not report original fMRI data in healthy adults.

fMRI study using an interactive trust game (a social processing task) with a healthy control group. However, participant ages are reported as 13–19, so it is unclear from the abstract whether at least one healthy group member falls within the required 17–65 range. Insufficient age detail—include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Event-related fMRI study in healthy human subjects performing a social-communication task (gaze and pointing cue processing). Directly investigates social-related processing in healthy adults; not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

Functional MRI study in healthy adult participants performing an emotional face observation/imitation task (social-related processing). Final sample of 20 adults; not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study using theory-of-mind social cognition tasks and includes a healthy control group (n=14). Abstract does not report participant ages (17–65 criterion unclear), so include for full-text review to confirm age and other eligibility.

fMRI study investigating theory-of-mind/social processing (responses to social vs non-social unexpected events) in human participants; targets social cognition in healthy adults and is not a review. Abstract provides sufficient info to include for full-text review.

Participants are Latin-American preadolescents (not age 17–65 adults). Although fMRI social cognition task used, sample age falls outside inclusion range, so study does not meet the adult healthy participant criterion.

Study uses resting-state fMRI in children aged 3–5 and examines intrinsic connectivity development. It is not a task-based fMRI of social processing in healthy adults (17–65), so it fails both task and population criteria.

fMRI study in healthy volunteers explicitly assessing theory-of-mind (cooperation vs deception), a social-processing task (perception/understanding of others). Not a review; meets inclusion criteria for healthy adult social fMRI studies.

Sample comprises adolescents (not healthy adults aged 17–65) and the fMRI measures described (risk processing, cognitive control) are not clearly social-related tasks. The abstract does not indicate fMRI of social processing in healthy adults, so it fails the review’s population and task criteria.

The study reports structural MRI and resting-state fMRI analyses in a cohort of individuals with autism spectrum disorder; it does not describe task-based fMRI of social processing in healthy adult participants (17–65). Therefore it does not meet the review’s inclusion criteria.

Resting-state fMRI in young children (mean age 4.98) under sedation; not a task-based social-processing fMRI study and participants are well below the 17–65 adult age range. Does not meet inclusion criteria.

This article is a narrative review of aIPS across species rather than an original fMRI study. It explicitly states 'we review,' indicating a review/meta-analytic format; thus it meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses and does not report primary fMRI data on healthy adults.

fMRI study in healthy adults on self-face recognition (perception/understanding of self), a social-related task. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient detail to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study investigating impression updating (perception/understanding of others), a social cognitive task. Abstract describes neural responses during social evaluation of individuals; no indication it is a review. Although participant age/health not explicitly stated, the study likely used healthy adult participants; include for full-text review to confirm demographics and methods.

Functional MRI study measuring mirror-system responses during observation of actions, directly relevant to social cognition/perception of others. Participants are healthy adults (no clinical groups reported) and the study is original research, not a review. Meets inclusion criteria; no exclusion criteria met. Abstract lacks specific ages, but this warrants inclusion for full-text review if needed.

Primary fMRI study (n=18) investigating social cognition (predicting others' behavior; theory-of-mind vs deontic inference) in human participants. Participants appear to be healthy adults and the task is social-related. Not a review or meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria.

Event-related fMRI study of emotion-word processing (social/affective language) vs control words; addresses social-communication/affective processing and reports data from typically-developing control participants (healthy group). Include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and extract relevant social-related contrasts.

Title and abstract indicate neural (fMRI) investigation of social cooperation/non-cooperation during a dyadic social interaction involving psychopathic traits. This fits the review objective (social processing) and likely includes healthy adults; meets inclusion criteria. Full text should be checked for participant ages and confirmation of fMRI methods, but abstract provides sufficient grounds to include for full-text review.

Functional MRI study using a social interactive task (virtual handshake) comparing social rejection vs acceptance. Includes a healthy control group (n=16). Not a review/meta-analysis. Ages not specified in abstract, but criteria allow inclusion if healthy adult group is present; include for full-text review to confirm age range.

fMRI study examining social processing (pupillary exchange/social salience) in human participants. Abstract reports healthy subjects but does not specify ages (17–65 requirement unclear). Not a review. Insufficient age detail—include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

The abstract explicitly states this is a review of model-based fMRI approaches ('we review model-based approaches'), not an original empirical fMRI study. As a review/meta-analytic article, it meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews or meta-analyses.

Study used fMRI during social-related tasks (empathy/sympathy). Participant sample includes healthy individuals aged 7–40, which contains adults within the 17–65 range required. Not a review or meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of pain empathy (social processing: perception/understanding of others) that included a healthy control group (n=21) of adults; task-based functional imaging meets inclusion criteria. Not a review or meta-analysis.

fMRI study measuring hemodynamic responses during explicit social trait judgments (trustworthiness, attractiveness) of voices in 44 healthy adult participants. Fits review objective on social processing in healthy adults; not a review or meta-analysis.

fMRI study of social (Theory of Mind) processing meets the task requirement. However participants are autistic and typically developing adolescents; the abstract does not confirm that any healthy participants are adults aged 17–65. Insufficient age information to determine eligibility, so include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and group composition.

fMRI study of social-perception (direct vs averted gaze) with a matched healthy control group (n=23). Abstract indicates social-related processing in humans; ages not specified, so include for full-text review to confirm age range (17–65).

The fMRI task assesses reward processing (monetary incentives and object-image incentives) rather than social-related processing. Although healthy control participants are included, the stimuli and task do not target social constructs (e.g., affiliation, social communication, perception of others), so it does not meet the review objective.

Study used fMRI while participants performed a social attribution/mentalizing task and included a healthy control group. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract indicates social cognitive processing during scanning; meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of face perception (social/emotional processing) using Thatcher illusion; includes a matched neurotypical control group of young adults (healthy participants within 17–65). Task is social-related (perception/understanding of others). Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information for inclusion.

fMRI study where healthy adult males (n=93) performed a social provocation/aggression task (Taylor aggression paradigm) during scanning, probing social cognition/response to others. Participants are healthy adults within target age range; not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

FMRI study of Theory of Mind/intentional causality (social cognition). Abstract reports group differences with reduced TPJ response in participants with ASD, implying a healthy control group was included. Fits review objective. Abstract lacks explicit participant ages and full sample details, so include for full-text review to confirm adult (17–65) healthy participant group and other eligibility criteria.

This article is a multi-method review/meta-analytic synthesis (includes Neurosynth analyses, lesion, TMS, MVPA evidence) rather than a primary fMRI study reporting functional MRI data collected from participants performing social tasks. It meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.

fMRI was performed during a validated social exclusion task (Cyberball), a social-processing paradigm. The study includes a healthy control group of adult women (likely within 17–65) and is not a review. Therefore it meets criteria for fMRI social-related processing in healthy adults.
Study used resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based social processing paradigm. Inclusion requires fMRI during a social-related task; therefore it does not meet the review criterion.

fMRI study addressing social processing (racial prejudice influencing disgust perception) using a passive viewing task. Abstract does not specify participant health status or ages (17–65). Insufficient sample detail to confirm eligibility, so include for full-text review to verify healthy adult sample and age range.

fMRI study examining social communication (prosodic decoding of communicative intentions), clearly a social-related task engaging mentalizing and auditory systems. Not a review. Abstract does not state participant ages or explicit health status; include for full-text to confirm sample meets 17–65 healthy adult criterion.

Study used fMRI during a social attribution task (inferring causes of avatar emotional behavior) and includes a healthy control group (n=16). The abstract does not report participant ages, so full text is needed to confirm they fall within 17–65 and to extract details. Include for full-text review.

fMRI was conducted while participants viewed emotional faces (a social cognition task—perception/understanding of others). The study includes a healthy control group (n=10) alongside HD carriers. Meets inclusion criteria; not a review. Confidence high.

fMRI study with healthy subjects performing a familiarity judgment for personally familiar, famous, and unfamiliar faces—this is a social cognition task (perception/understanding of others). Participants are described as healthy adults; not a review. Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study with healthy subjects (N=30) performing gender identification of angry and happy faces—an implicit social-emotional task involving perception/understanding of others. Meets inclusion (social-related fMRI in healthy adults). Not a review; no indication participants are outside 17–65. Includes social task even though non-social control present.

The study used fMRI during an emotional face recognition task (social processing: perception/understanding of others). It includes healthy adult participants (mothers without current mental disorders) alongside a comparison group, and is an original research article (not a review). Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social-processing studies in healthy adults.

fMRI study with healthy adult (college-age) participants performing a task that involves social perspective and fan-group identity (social cognition). The task examines emotional memory retrieval influenced by fan’s perspective/valence, fitting 'perception and understanding of self/others' and social processing. Not a review.

Reports original fMRI studies in (adult) healthy participants examining persuasion, a social-cognitive process (mentalizing/social cognition) using text and video stimuli. Fits the review’s focus on social-related processing in healthy adults and is not a review or meta-analysis.

fMRI study investigating animacy perception and social cognitive processes in humans, linking to social neural network and mirror neuron system. Meets review objective of social-related processing. Abstract does not explicitly state participant ages/health status; insufficient detail to confirm but likely healthy adults — include for full-text review to verify eligibility.

Abstract reports an fMRI task in 61 healthy adult (white male) participants examining neural processing of race and socioeconomic status—perception/understanding of others—meeting the review’s social-related fMRI inclusion criteria. No exclusion criteria apparent.
Study used fMRI during social exclusion but participants were adolescents (13-year-olds), which falls outside the review’s age inclusion range (17–65). Therefore it does not meet the age criterion.

The task probes pain anticipation and fear of movement, not social processing. Although healthy controls are included and authors reference social-cognition brain regions, the stimuli (back-straining vs neutral exercises) and measures target pain/fear, not social-related constructs; therefore it does not meet the review objective.

The article is a quantitative meta-analysis of 35 fMRI studies rather than an original fMRI study with primary participant data. The review's exclusion criteria explicitly exclude systematic reviews or meta-analyses.

fMRI study investigating integration of facial and vocal emotional expressions (social perception/communication). Uses whole-brain and ROI analyses and healthy human participants are implied; not a review or clinical-only sample. Relevant to social processing in adults.

fMRI study with 42 healthy adult participants performing a social-related task (self vs. other processing regarding romantic partner) addressing affiliation/attachment and perception/understanding of self and others. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient detail to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI data were collected while healthy adult football supporters watched matches—a naturalistic social task probing group bias/social cognition (affiliation/interpretation). The study examines neural correlates of social group processing and is not a review/meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study using an explicit social reward task (agreement with music experts) and includes a matched stimulant-naive healthy control group, meeting inclusion criteria for social processing in healthy adults.

The study used resting-state fMRI (rfMRI) rather than a task-based social processing paradigm. Inclusion requires fMRI during a social-related task; although participants are healthy adults, no social task was performed, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of social intention understanding in 27 healthy adult participants; tasks involved processing cooperative vs affective social interactions (social cognition). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides necessary info to meet inclusion criteria.

Study used resting-state fMRI rather than task-based fMRI of social processing. Although it includes a healthy control group, the scanner was not used during a social-related task, so it does not meet the inclusion criterion requiring fMRI during a social task.

Abstract describes an fMRI study of social-related processes (imitation/observation, mirror neuron system). The abstract does not explicitly state presence of a healthy control group aged 17–65. Insufficient information to rule out inclusion, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy participant group and age range.

Abstract reports functional neural (fMRI) responses during a socio-affective task (witnessing others' distress), involves healthy adult participants undergoing compassion training versus control, and examines social-affective processing (empathy/affiliation). Not a review/meta-analysis. Fits inclusion criteria.

Abstract describes an fMRI study of Theory of Mind (a social processing task) but does not specify presence of a healthy control group or participant ages. Inclusion unclear from abstract alone; include for full-text review to confirm whether healthy adults (age 17–65) were included.

fMRI study where participants imagined personally familiar others (social cognition/perception of others). Abstract does not report participant ages or explicit health status; likely healthy adult sample. Include for full-text review to confirm sample characteristics and eligibility.

Primary fMRI study (three experiments) investigating dynamic vs. static facial expressions, clearly addressing social perception/processing. Although the abstract includes an ALE meta-analysis, the paper reports original fMRI experiments in humans. Abstract lacks explicit participant age/health details, so include for full-text review to confirm sample fits 17–65 healthy adults.

Original fMRI study where participants performed a social-related task (gender discrimination of emotional faces — perception/understanding of others). Reports data from healthy adults (genotype comparison); not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria for social fMRI in healthy adults.

This is a resting-state fMRI study (no task-based social processing) in Williams syndrome patients and matched controls. It does not involve a social-related task in healthy adult participants, so it fails the inclusion criteria.

The task used (Embedded Figures Task) is a visuospatial/perceptual task, not a social-related task. Although healthy control participants are included and results relate to social symptom severity in autism, the fMRI contrast does not probe social processing per the review inclusion criteria.

fMRI study using an explicit empathizing task (social processing of self/others) with a typically developing control group. Abstract reports ages 12–31 for participants but does not specify how many controls are ≥17. Insufficient detail to confirm the healthy control group fully meets the 17–65 adult criterion, so include for full-text review.

The study used resting-state fMRI rather than a task-based social paradigm, and participants are adolescents (autistic and neurotypical), not clearly within the adult 17–65 range. It therefore does not meet the requirement for task-based fMRI of social processing in healthy adults.

fMRI study of social processing (perception of affective facial expressions). Includes at least one healthy adult sample (independent North American replication, n=85). Not a systematic review. Age range not specified in abstract, but adults are implied; per instructions, include when unclear for full-text review.

Abstract describes neurocognitive studies of information sharing but does not specify that a functional MRI was used, nor participant demographics/ages. Insufficient detail to determine eligibility based on fMRI and age criteria—include for full-text review.

Study used resting-state fMRI (dynamic functional connectivity) and did not report any social-related task or task-based social processing. Although healthy controls were included, absence of a social task means it does not meet the inclusion criteria.

The fMRI task examined sensorimotor control (saccadic and pursuit eye movements), not social-related processing. Although healthy control participants were included, the study does not meet the requirement that participants performed a social-related task.

fMRI study of joint attention (a social cognition task) conducted during real-time interaction; includes healthy adult neurotypical comparison groups (mean age-matched adults, n=14 and n=22). Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults; not a review.

Abstract lacks clear information that an fMRI social-processing task was used and whether the sample includes healthy adults aged 17–65. Title suggests neural activation in unaffected siblings (likely healthy) but social nature of task is unclear. Include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

Task-based fMRI in healthy adult participants (congenitally blind and sighted) examined neural responses to observing and recognizing others’ actions and motor pantomime, probing perception/understanding of others (a social-related construct). Fits inclusion criteria (healthy adults, social processing, task-based fMRI) and is not a review.

The study reports an fMRI task where adults underwent socially-induced cognitive emotion regulation (a social-processing task involving a psychotherapist) and includes measures of attachment/social functioning. Participants are described as adults with no indication they are a clinical-only sample. This directly fits the review objective and inclusion criteria, and it is not a review/meta-analysis.

Event-related fMRI study (n=51) of affective speech comprehension involving emotional sentence classification and theory-of-mind/social cognition networks in healthy adults. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract implies a healthy adult sample performing a social-related task; include for full-text review to confirm age range and health status.

Participants are young children with autism spectrum disorder; no group of healthy adults (age 17–65) is included. Although the fMRI task assessed social processing, the population does not meet the review’s required healthy adult sample, so the study should be excluded.

fMRI study with healthy adult participants performing a social decision-making task (responses to being controlled by another person). Assesses social cognitions and neural activity; not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI was used while mothers viewed ecologically valid infant videos probing attachment/affiliation (social processing). Participants are healthy adult mothers (typical adult age range). Study directly assesses social/affiliative neural processing; no exclusion criteria met. Included for full-text data extraction.

fMRI study in healthy adult participants performing empathy/emotion-attribution tasks (SELF and OTHER), which are social-related processes. Meets inclusion criteria; not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text review.

Study examines brain activation during emotion processing (a social cognition task) in unaffected siblings of schizophrenia patients—i.e., healthy participants at genetic risk. It appears to use neuroimaging to assess emotion-related neural activity, fitting the fMRI social-processing objective. Abstract lacks explicit ages and scanner details, so include for full-text review to confirm methods and participant ages.

fMRI study directly examines anticipatory processes during active interpersonal touch (human vs inanimate), addressing social processing (perception/understanding of others). Human participants underwent fMRI; abstract lacks explicit age/health details, so include for full-text review to confirm eligibility.

Original fMRI study investigating perception of social actions (perception/understanding of others) in lateral occipitotemporal cortex. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not report participant ages/health but likely healthy adults; per screening rules, include for full-text review when information is insufficient.

This is a narrative review of neuroimaging findings in autism, not a primary fMRI study. The abstract describes an integrative review and does not report original fMRI experiments with healthy adult participants performing social tasks, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

This publication is a systematic review and meta-analysis of fMRI studies rather than an original fMRI study of healthy adult participants performing social tasks; it meets the exclusion criterion for systematic reviews/meta-analyses.
Study is an animal (mouse) resting-state fMRI/structural connectome investigation; no human participants or social-task fMRI data. Does not meet inclusion criteria.

Study used resting-state fMRI (rsfMRI) and event-related potentials, not a task-based fMRI during a social-related task. The review requires functional MRI performed while participants engaged in a social task, so this does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining effects of expert advice (social influence) on decision-making; includes a healthy adult group (18+). Task involves social cognition processes (advice uptake), meeting social-related processing criterion. Not a review.

fMRI study with 46 healthy adult volunteers performing theory-of-mind/social cognition tasks (emotion, beliefs, pain). Investigates perception/understanding of others, matches review objective. Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient detail to include for full-text assessment.

fMRI was used while healthy adult participants viewed and learned faces—tasks involving perception and recognition of others (social cognition). Participants were healthy adults; study is original research, not a review. Abstract provides sufficient detail to include for full-text data extraction.

The study used EEG (electrophysiological) methods rather than functional MRI; inclusion requires a functional MRI scan during a social-related task. Although it involves social/gossip processing in healthy adults, the imaging modality does not meet the review’s fMRI criterion.

Four fMRI experiments (n=98) in healthy adults involving social-cognitive tasks (judgments about self, friends, unknown others) addressing perception/understanding of self and others. Not a review or meta-analysis; meets inclusion criteria.

fMRI study examining social interaction (initiating/responding to joint attention) using an interactive virtual-reality task in human participants. Abstract indicates primary imaging research relevant to social processing; however participant ages/health not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm demographics and eligibility.

The paper studies birdsong and discusses fMRI data from songbirds (non-human). It does not report functional MRI in healthy human adults performing social-related tasks, so it does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of auditory emotion perception (social communication/perception of others) in human listeners. The abstract reports functional neuroimaging of voice-emotion processing, meeting the social-related task and fMRI criteria. Participant health/age not specified, so include for full-text review to confirm healthy adults (17–65).

fMRI study examining attachment-related processing of masked emotional faces (social/affiliation domain) in a sample of 51 healthy adults. Fits inclusion: functional MRI during social-related task and healthy adult participants; not a review.

Human fMRI study involving healthy adult men (n=20) performing a social-related task (viewing romantic images), which maps onto affiliation/attachment. Not a review or meta-analysis. Sufficient information in abstract to meet inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in adults.

Study used 3T fMRI during a multiround trust game (a social-related task) and included a healthy comparison group of women. It directly addresses social processing in humans, meeting inclusion criteria. No exclusion criteria apply.

The study used disruptive transcranial magnetic stimulation (TMS) and behavioral measures, not functional MRI. Although it examines social processes (perspective-taking), it does not report fMRI data collected during task performance, so it does not meet the fMRI-inclusion criterion.

The study used resting-state fMRI (rsFC) rather than an fMRI scan conducted during a social-related task. Although it examines peer influences on brain connectivity, no social task was performed during scanning; thus it does not meet the task-based social processing inclusion criterion.

Study used fMRI BOLD in healthy participants watching short film scenes that evoke emotional (social) conflicts and examined brain regions (STS, IPL) implicated in social cognition. Task involves perception/evaluation of others’ emotions, meeting the social-related processing criterion. Not a review.

Abstract addresses parental brain and biobehavioral synchrony (a social processing topic) but does not report use of fMRI, participant ages, or task details. Insufficient methodological information to confirm inclusion criteria; include for full-text review to verify fMRI social-task and healthy adult participants.

fMRI study of social-related processing (self/other evaluations) that includes a healthy young adult group aged 22–31, which falls within the 17–65 inclusion range. Not a review; methods meet criteria.
fMRI study examining trustworthiness appraisal (social perception) comparing BPD participants to controls; includes at least one healthy control group and uses a social-related task. Not a review.

fMRI study in 21 healthy adult men performing a social-evaluation task (receiving negative social feedback). This examines neural processing of social information in healthy adults within the 17–65 age range and is not a review; therefore meets inclusion criteria.

Original fMRI study in healthy participants examining recognition of visual feedback of own versus others’ movements — relevant to perception/understanding of self and others (social cognition). Not a review. Age range not specified in abstract, so include for full-text review to confirm participant ages and other details.

Empirical fMRI study in healthy participants manipulating first-person bodily perspective during a social interaction; examines perception/understanding of self and reports hippocampal activity. Meets inclusion (fMRI during social-related/self-processing, healthy adults). Not a review. Include for full-text to confirm ages and details.
The study used positron emission tomography (PET), not functional MRI; therefore it fails the inclusion criterion requiring an fMRI scan during a social-related task.

The article is a review paper (abstract states 'This review presents results...'), not an original fMRI study with primary human data. The exclusion criteria disallow systematic reviews/meta-analyses, so exclude.

fMRI study of healthy adult subjects performing emotion-recognition from dynamic avatars (perception/understanding of others), a social-related task. Methods and population fit inclusion criteria; not a review or meta-analysis. Clear from abstract.

fMRI study in typically developing adult participants performing a social perception task (viewing others' eye gaze). Examines neural responses in social attention/Perception of Others network. Participants described as typical adults (healthy), not a review/meta-analysis. Satisfies inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports task-based fMRI during a facial emotion processing task (social-related processing). Study includes a healthy control group (27 controls). Not a review/meta-analysis. Therefore meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults; full text can confirm ages if needed.

Study used functional MRI during a social-rejection (Cyberball) task, a social-related paradigm, and includes a group of healthy adult participants alongside adolescents. Not a review/meta-analysis. Meets inclusion criteria for fMRI social processing in healthy adults.

Abstract reports imaging of neural activity in response to emotional face processing (a social perception task), fitting the review objective. However, participant health status and ages are not specified in the abstract, so full-text review is needed to confirm inclusion criteria (healthy adults 17–65).

Participants are described as adolescents (not adults). The study examines autism and siblings; no clear group of healthy adults aged 17–65 is reported. Therefore it does not meet the inclusion requirement of at least one healthy adult group (17–65).
Participants were children in middle childhood (ages 8–12), which falls outside the review’s required adult age range (17–65); thus the study does not meet inclusion criteria.

Human fMRI study examining cross-modal recognition of other individuals (face/voice), i.e. perception and understanding of others — a social processing task. Involves human participants (presumably healthy adults) and is not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract contains sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Study used fMRI during a task involving contemplation of parents (social/affiliation/attachment processing) and included a healthy volunteer group. Not a review. Abstract gives sufficient evidence of social-related fMRI data in healthy adults to warrant inclusion for full-text data extraction (age ranges can be confirmed in full text).

Resting-state fMRI was recorded after presentation of standardized critical remarks (a social-evaluative stimulus) in a sample of healthy adults (n=48). Although this is not a traditional task-based paradigm, the study explicitly assesses neural processing of social criticism; include for full-text review to confirm task timing, stimulus during scan, and participant health/age details.

Primary fMRI study using an interactive social task (Prisoner’s Dilemma) in healthy adult males and females, directly assessing social processing. Not a review or meta-analysis; meets inclusion criteria for the review.

This article is a systematic review and meta-analysis of oxytocin imaging studies, which meets the exclusion criterion (systematic reviews/meta-analyses). Abstract clearly indicates it is a meta-analysis, so exclude based on abstract alone.

This is a meta-analysis of fMRI studies in schizophrenia (systematic review/meta-analysis) and explicitly includes studies of patients with ICD/DSM diagnoses; it is a meta-analysis (excluded) and does not report primary data from healthy adult groups as required.

Abstract describes fMRI of cognitive emotion regulation to positive/negative pictures but does not mention social stimuli or social cognitive processes (affiliation, communication, self/other perception). Although participants likely healthy adults, the task is not social-related. Exclude for not addressing the review objective.

fMRI study using an implicit facial emotion task (fear vs neutral), which is social-related processing (perception/understanding of others). Includes a matched healthy control group alongside patients. Not a review/meta-analysis. Therefore meets inclusion criteria.

This paper is a meta-analysis (activation likelihood estimation) of fMRI studies on psychopathy. The exclusion criteria disallow systematic reviews or meta-analyses; additionally, the focus is on psychopath populations rather than primary fMRI in healthy adults.

fMRI study where healthy participants processed social communication (text messages believed sent by a friend vs a computer), examining social-context modulation of neural responses (social communication/understanding of others). Not a review or meta-analysis; meets inclusion criteria.

The article is explicitly a review and meta-analysis ('A review and meta-analysis'), which meets the exclusion criterion disallowing systematic reviews/meta-analyses. Although it summarizes neuroimaging studies, it is not an original fMRI study of healthy adults and thus should be excluded.

Study used resting-state fMRI connectivity analyses rather than a task-based fMRI paradigm assessing social-related processing. Although healthy control participants were included, the review requires fMRI during a social task; this criterion is not met.

Event-related fMRI in healthy adult nulliparous women examining neural responses to infant cries and faces—clearly social-related processing (perception/understanding of others; affiliation/attachment). Participants are healthy adults, and this is an original fMRI study rather than a review. Abstract provides sufficient information.
Abstract is incomplete and does not specify whether an fMRI social task was used or whether a healthy adult (17–65) group was included. Include for full-text review to determine eligibility.

Abstract describes resting-state fMRI and coactivation-based parcellation of left IPL; it does not clearly state that participants performed a social-related task in the scanner, nor give participant details. Although a subregion is associated with social cognition, the abstract lacks explicit in-scanner social task data. Insufficient information to determine exclusion—include for full-text review.

The study used MEG (with anatomical MRI for source reconstruction) rather than functional MRI. The inclusion criterion requires functional MRI conducted during a social-related task, so the imaging modality requirement is not met.

Task-based fMRI study examining self-referential processing (a social-related construct: perception/understanding of self). Includes a healthy control group (n=23), but ages not reported in the abstract (likely older adults). Insufficient age information—include for full-text review.

Functional MRI study of theory-of-mind (implicit and explicit belief processing), a social cognition task (perception/understanding of others). Involves human participants (presumably healthy adults) and is an original empirical fMRI study, not a review. Meets inclusion criteria for social-related fMRI in healthy adults.

Original fMRI study investigating self-referential processing and perspective taking (social cognition) in human participants; fits review objective (perception/understanding of self and others). Appears to involve healthy adults and is not a review/meta-analysis.

Study examines multisensory integration and functional connectivity in autism spectrum disorder and relates abnormalities to clinical severity. Abstract does not describe a social-related fMRI task nor report a healthy adult participant group (17–65). Therefore it does not meet the review inclusion criteria.

Study used resting-state fMRI (no task-based social processing) and reports findings in individuals with autism; no evidence of a healthy adult task group aged 17–65. Does not meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI event-related paradigm examined gesture planning and execution (social action/communication). Study included a healthy control group (25 adults) matched for age, gender, education. Task relates to social processing (gesturing/social interaction). Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of supraliminal fearful face processing (social/emotional perception) including a healthy adult control group (n=25). Not a review/meta-analysis. Fits criteria of social-related task and healthy participants aged as adults.

The study uses resting-state connectivity, meta-analytic connectivity modeling, and structural covariance; it does not report a task-based fMRI paradigm involving social-related processing. Although it discusses social cognition, no in-scanner social task with healthy participants is described, so it fails the inclusion criteria.

fMRI study of perspective-taking during self/other referential processing (social cognition). Includes a typically developed healthy adult control group alongside ASD group, satisfying the requirement for healthy participants aged as adults. Not a review or meta-analysis.

Abstract reports fMRI of social-related processes (self-referential processing and perspective-taking) but does not clearly state whether a healthy control group (age 17–65) was included. Insufficient information to confirm inclusion criteria from abstract alone—include for full-text review.

Empirical fMRI study of cognitive empathy (social processing) with a healthy control group (n=24). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract does not report participant ages; include for full-text review to confirm ages (17–65) and extract data.

Study used fMRI during a social-related task (emotion recognition with eye-gaze), includes a healthy younger adult group aged 17–27 which meets the age criterion (17–65). Not a review/meta-analysis. Abstract provides sufficient information to include for full-text screening.

Hyperscanning fMRI of joint attention is a social-interaction task directly relevant to review. Abstract does not state participant ages or explicit healthy status; therefore include for full-text review to confirm sample (age 17–65 and healthy) meets inclusion criteria.
Study samples children and adolescents with autism; abstract does not report a healthy adult (age 17–65) participant group. Does not meet inclusion criterion requiring healthy adults. Not a review.

Abstract implies study of amygdala response to emotional faces (a social processing task) but does not explicitly state fMRI or the presence of healthy control group. Insufficient detail in abstract to determine criteria, so include for full-text review to confirm imaging modality and sample composition.

The study used resting-state fMRI, not a task-based fMRI conducted while participants performed a social-related task. Although social cognition (emotion/sarcasm recognition) was measured behaviorally, no fMRI data were reported from a social processing task. Therefore it does not meet the requirement for task-based social fMRI.

Study examined neural correlates of autistic traits in neurotypical adults and used fMRI functional connectivity in a region implicated in social cognition. Abstract does not specify whether scanning occurred during a social-related task versus resting-state; information is insufficient to apply inclusion criteria definitively. Include for full-text review to determine task-based social processing and participant ages.

fMRI study of social-emotional processing (fearful face perception) using stimuli that probe social brain areas; includes a matched healthy adult control group (adults) alongside HFA/AS participants. Not a review. Abstract provides sufficient information to meet inclusion criteria.

Abstract reports human oxytocin effects on processing of socially relevant cues in the VTA, aligning with social processing in humans. However the abstract does not explicitly state that fMRI was used or that participants were healthy adults aged 17–65. Insufficient methodological/participant detail—include for full-text review to confirm imaging modality and sample characteristics.

Study used resting-state fMRI (no social-related task performed) and did not include measures of social processing; although healthy control groups were present, the meta-analysis requires task-based social processing — exclude.

Abstract investigates neural correlates of facial emotion processing (social stimuli: faces) in individuals at risk for psychosis. This aligns with social-related processing. Although the abstract does not explicitly state fMRI or state inclusion of a healthy control group, NeuroImage publication and context suggest neuroimaging and likely controls; information is insufficient to confirm eligibility, so include for full-text review.

Resting-state fMRI (no social-related task) in antipsychotic-naive adolescents. Does not investigate social processing during a task, and healthy participants are adolescents (not adults 17–65) — does not meet inclusion criteria.
